Truly... one of the very best group of employees at a hotel....VERY attentive and kind.

review_content: Very nice hotel, located in downtown Louisville (aka Looavul, Luhvul, Looeyville, Looaville, Lou-e-ville)!Location:  The hotel is convenient to 4th Street Live, across the street from the Louisville International Convention Center (hotel connects to the Convention Center through a skywalk) and a few blocks from the Louisville Slugger Museum & Factory, KFC Yum!  Center (home of the UL Cardinals and @ 20k+ seat concert venue), Muhammad Ali Center, Kentucky Center for Performing Arts (3 theaters: 2,400, 600+ and 139),  Louisville Palace Theater and Louisville Waterfront Park.First Impression:  they provide Valet parking in the front of the hotel on E. Jefferson and guest underground parking garage located around the corner on W. Liberty St.  The lobby is usually decorated nicely, especially festive for the holidays w/ plenty of seating (3 seperate areas with couches and chairs).The front desk/concierge is located to the left and usually has 2-3 staff for check-in (+ check-in kiosk for elite Marriott members).  I've stayed at this hotel 5 times and have never waited long.Rooms: very clean, modern and comfortable.  All rooms have large comfortable beds (either 2 double or king), flat screen TV's, refrigerators, medium-sized closet, desk and chair w/ ottoman.  The views are ok, I suggest staying above the 15th floor to get better views.  Note:  the 16th floor has the concierge room, which provides breakfast (starts at 6am).Ameneties:  Fitness Center, Business Center, Indoor Pool/Hot Tub, Indoor Parking Garage and Onsite StarbucksFood/Drinks:  there are 2 restaurants in the lobby of the hotel:  Blu Italian Grille and Champions Sports Bar and Grill, Bourbon Bar and Starbucks (next to the front desk).  They also have a small store that has snacks, drinks, toiletries, medications and gifts.I ate at Blu Italian Grille twice and both meals were good (I had the Filet w/ side of Crab Mac & Cheese and Salmon), but fairly pricey.  I have also had a quick snack and dessert in Champions, which is a Sports Bar with pretty good casual bar food and drinks with plenty of TV's to watch the games.  Good place for larger groups.Final thoughts:  the Downtown Louisville Marriott is a very clean, comfortable, convenient hotel for anyone that wants to stay in downtown Louisville.  I like that if you are weary from your travels and want to stay in the hotel, you have good food choices, a gym, business center and indoor pool.  If you want to venture out, there are plenty of restaurant and venue choices in all directions.Skip the other local "historic" choices, this Marriott is the place to stay in Louisville- Safe travels!Justin Johnson, the front desk receptionist ensured that our stay here was beyond great. Upon learning of our stay we remembered us for our duration (four nights) and every time our paths crossed he made sure we felt welcome.  His willingness to go above and beyond his duties is one warranted for myself to recommend a stay at this Marriott and return in the future. He is knowledgeable of the area and gives great recommendations for any type of entertainment, food, etc that you may be looking for in the area.I called the same day we checked in and the rate was residual its. However they do a military rate which have us $100 off! Phew we will take that for sure! The hotel is actually very pretty inside. The staff was very friendly. It has champions sports grill and bar, and also a bourbon bar if you are just looking to have a night cap. The room was clean and the beds were comfortable. Overall our stay was great. We only laid out head down and were not here for more than 8 hours but it was at least a comfortable 8hrs. If we come back to Louisville and stay over again I will def be coming back here.Our school stayed at the Marriott for one night.  All of our rooms were clean and tidy.  The beds were absolutely comfortable.  We all really enjoyed our stay.  All of the staff were extremely polite and helpful.  When we come back to Louisville for the state convention next year, we will absolutely stay at the Marriott again!Christmas brunch was over all good waffles roast beef and coffee was excellent i had some attitude problems with one of the managers over my service dog Kiki but they took half off my bill so I am happyI was so not pleased at all with this so called "4star" hotel. The bedding felt like shower curtains, u had to pay $27 for parking (which they dont tell u when u make reservations) and good luck trying to get out of there parking garage there exit signs r not helpful, took us 30 minutes to even find our way out with the help of someone. The maid knocked twice told her to hang on, she still walks in my room even after telling her. No complimentary breakfast. Atleast at motel 6 you get that. I would of rather of stayed at one of them. I will not ever stay at a Marriott hotel again.Great hotel very clean and well maintained staff is very attentive. Walking distance to most anything downtownI haven't stayed in this hotel yet, so I can't speak on that, but I did go to a conference here and I can say that i was absolutely blown away. It was possibly the best food, most prompt and pleasant service, and constant attention I've ever received at any hotel or conference.  I'm sure it came with a price but at every turn there was someone waiting with water, fruits, treats, and you wanted for nothing during breakfast and lunch spread. At one point there was chocolate dipped strawberries, an ice cream bar, and a whole tray of full candies to choose from. My only semi-complaint was that the bathrooms were a bit far away from our conference rooms. It's a semi-complaint because with all that eating, it was probably for the best. To top it off, the location is superb - if I was an out-of-towner I would have loved being downtown during the evenings!My husband and I stayed at the Marriott in Downtown Louisville for a conference, leaving just today. Seven days of conference and other meetings and I have to say that this hotel has the most attentive and kind staff I've seen ANYWHERE! Staff were stationed in the lobby always checking to see if there was anything they could do to make our stay better.One gentleman whose name is Bill, seemed ever present. Last night at our banquet he and two other staff members were basically at attention as they watched and waited and on cue removed tables from the stage so we might honor our newly board certified chaplains.  He cued the waitstaff and kept the evening running smoothly. He became the staff member I went to with any need, partly because he was ALWAYS there when we needed assistance. Bill was who I went to when a colleague's hand was injured. Was the hotel perfect? No, but darn close! Bill, Cory and Eamon were the gentlemen whose names I remember: gracious, kind and engaging, always asking if there was anything we needed. The housekeepers were amazing and our server in Champions was both professional and engaging. I forget her name, but I remember her as the mom who took her daughter to see Taylor Swift the night before!Marriott Downtown Louisville has a formula for success that works! I recommend it highly, and even though its prices are above my regular budget, I might just save my pennies and return. I've been to enough conferences at enough hotels to know that this one is truly exceptional!Never have I had a worse experience with a hotel. Especially one that is supposed to be upscale.I stayed in the Marriott Downtown for 2 nights for a Bachelor Party weekend, and after arriving home an hour after checking out, I unpacked my bag only to realize that I had left my brand new, tailored white dress shirt hanging up in the room. No problem, I thought. I immediately called them, talked to a customer representative, and was assured that the dress shirt would "show up after the maid cleaned the room" and they would call me. Okay. I believed them. I called the next day -- nothing. I waited a few days, called again, and nope. Now it has been a month and 5 or so phone calls, and it looks like either a maid stole the shirt, or they lost it. My nicest, $150 dress shirt down the drain. I would expect this kind of service from a cheap Motel, but not a hotel of this price. Ridiculous.I'm a regular Marriott user, but this was the worst Marriott experience I've had to date. I arrived at 10pm after a long day of travel to find out they had oversold the hotel and they would be moving me to the Hyatt next door. Ok, so much for reserving 4 months in advance! Well my room at the Hyatt was a welcome upgrade and the walk to the Marriott where all my meetings were being held wasn't bad. In fact, the Hyatt room had been newly reconstructed and was a welcome place to sleep. That evening I was locked out of my room at the Hyatt and informed I had to go back to the Marriott because the Hyatt was sold out. So I packed up to spend my 2nd night at the Marriott. Disappointing room! OMG the comforter felt like it was made of plastic and linen. Glad I'm not sleeping in that room again. And the room was tired and in need of an upgrade.When the power went out in our hotel nearby, we were relocated to the Marriott. It was actually really easy to get to and checking in was very easy. The hotel is very nice and modern. The lobby with the decorations for the Holiday season were just beautiful and festive.We were given a nice King Suite at the same rate as the other hotel for the night. We liked the room and considered staying at the Marriott instead, but we ended up just staying for the night. They were very accommodating to all of the guests that needed to be relocated.Pretty hotel and good location. It's pricey as are all the downtown hotels,  but really nice if you want to go out to eat or to a show. The indoor pool is a nice plus if you want to take a dip. The beds were not as comfortable as I would have liked and I'm usually pretty easy to please. We were only there for one night so didn't spend much time in the hotel. We were a bit disappointed in the morning to find a long wait for brunch at the restaurant, even though there were a lot of open tables and there was a brunch buffet- we ended up going somewhere else.This hotel is your average Midwestern downtown Marriott...clean, courteous staff, and comfortable. Though we stayed on a Saturday night, the hotel was a ghost-town as was the rest of the neighborhood.  The bar had last call at 11:30.  Worse, the Starbucks in the hotel, the only place to get a decent cup of coffee in the area, wasn't opening until 9:30 am.  Because of this I'll never stay at this hotel again....not sure if I'll ever stay downtown in Louisville again!Recently stayed here while in town for a concert.  The location is outstanding if you don't need to leave the downtown area, everything is pretty much within walking distance.  The staff is very friendly and always ask if they can assist you with anything.I saw/heard some live music on my way out of the lobby this morning, I think they had a jazz quartet for Sunday brunch...nice.  They could stand to upgrade the towels and toiletries, but those are the only changes I'd recommend.Clean, nice, friendly. Short walk to restaurants & bars. Stay here for an RV convention and they are very attentive to customers.It'll get the job done, especially if you're traveling for business.Although I didn't spend too much time at the hotel other than to change clothes and go (and lay my head for a few), I was satisfied with my stay.The lobby is grand and was beautifully decorated in spirit of the holiday season when I visited. There is a restaurant within as well as a sports bar adjacent. At the time I arrived, the restaurant was not yet open for dinner (although the lounge and bar area was) so I had to pop on over to the sports bar for a quick bite. The rooms were pretty traditional with few bells and whistles, but most importantly it was clean and comfortable. There is also a Starbuck's within the property, so no need to hunt that down if you're a 'bucks fiend. You can just head downstairs and grab it on your way out. Not the sexiest hotel out there by any means, but definitely a solid choice.Everything was great especially the staff. There are more unique places to stay downtown such as The Brown but the Marriott is very reliable. Since its not unique it would be nice if WiFi was free to have some kind of perk for staying at a run of the mill place.I am a Marriott fan, but this was a good one.  We were there for a convention and the banquet meals were much better than the usual rubber chicken.  Not only did they have a local flavor, they had good size portions and nicely sauced.The hotel itself has a great bourbon bar off the lobby and I much preferred that to going into Characters for a drink.  The wait staff was very knowledgeable about the bourbons and they offer the option of flights for tasting.The Marriott staff was the usual over-the-top friendly, the rooms nice, clean and comfortable and the maids had fun turning the towels into animals and shapes both when the room was made up and again at the turn-down service.First of all, it's a Marriott.  As far as Marriotts go, it is a nice one.  Clean, updated rooms.  Good, friendly service.  Stayed in the one-room suite.  Nice EXCEPT for the fact there are no plugs at the desk for devices.THE FOOD IS TERRIFIC!
review_content_20: Very well run hotel. Accommodating staff throughout. Comfortable, clean and quiet rooms. Champion Sports Bar serves excellent food. I'd certainly come back.Beautiful hotel and awesome costumer service. They have a nice pool/jacuzzi area next to a fitness center where my husband and I worked out. The workout room was small but convient. I loved eating breakfast at the Blu restaurant in the lobby, very delicious food. I would stay here again if I'm ever in the area.I was given a room for a business trip. Very nice hotel as you would expect from Marriott. Accommodating staff. Luxurious rooms and amenities. I wouldn't normally stay in this hotel as I seek out less pricey hotels but a great choice for those willing to pay. Parking is $27 per day so be sure to consider that when booking as well. No complaints for a free stay.We stayed here while we were in town for my brother-in-law's funeral. We were originally booked at another hotel, but a friend offered up her rewards points for us to stay at the Marriott. The room was nice, not what I would have expected for an upscale hotel, but no complaints, except that the wifi is $9.95 a day. I have never heard of a hotel charging for wifi. However, we were presented with a bill on our last day for the room and parking. We never parked in the Marriott garage, yet were charged $27/day for parking. We had been assured by Marriott several times that the room was covered under our friend's rewards points. We have called and talked to several people at Marriott (hotel and corporate) and they will not remove the charges from my card. Instead of paying $250 for the hotel I had originally booked, I now have to pay almost $600 for the room and parking fees that we didn't even incur. We confirmed with them several times before we checked in that the room was covered under the rewards points. I will never stay at this or any Marriott again. You can stay at a hotel that's equally as nice for a lot less, plus you won't have to pay for parking or wifi.Very comfortable hotel. Comfortable bed, adequate bathroom, good location. All of my needs were met while I was here.Looking forward, I think that this hotel will need some updating in the next 3-5 years to stay current. However, it will be well poised as a great downtown location because of great staff, clean rooms, comfortable beds, and a great location.If you've seen one Marriott, you've seen them all . . .and I mean that in a good way! With the Marriott chain being my preferred hotel chain- I have stayed at them all over the world and they consistently provide me with a functional. clean space during my stay. And that is pretty much the minimum for me!On this visit- I was here for all of about 10 hours- just long enough to sleep, make my presentation and head out.Located downtown- this Marriott has a large welcoming lobby area and friendly front desk staff (even after 11pm which I appreciated as I had had a horrendous time just getting here!). In fact, everyone was friendly here as they directed me around and made sure I had whatever it looked like I needed! They were out of my standard king bed so I ended up with two doubles but at this point I really didn't care. The room was clean, the bed was soft and I slept well. There is free in room coffee although you will be charged for Internet access (which drives me nuts as it is free in their lower end properties like Courtyard)The meeting rooms at this hotel are quite nice. Large with a nice reception hall on the side to host your pre function gathering or to lay out breakfast as was the case on my visit. And the bathrooms are perfectly located right across the hall from the ballroom . . .not down the hall and around a bend as is the case in many hotels.My final view of the graciousness of this hotel came from the bellman as he worked to find me a cab to the airport. "Thanks for visiting", said he.Now that just put a smile on my face!I was in town for a conference with a fellow co-worker last weekend. The stay was fine, decent room and location. The problem came with billing. I had pre-paid two rooms (one for me and one for my co-worker). The person at the front desk said he needed a credit card for incidentals only (because the room was prepaid). I asked him to verify the credit card I used to prepay and he did correctly. Come to find out, he charged my co-workers card for his room- not the credit card I had used to pre-pay. I have tried calling several times over several days to get this rectified. I am always transferred to accounting where I have been instructed to leave a message because they never can take my phone call. I have left messages and have called the hotel multiple times to no avail. Now, my co-worker over drafted his account and has fees associated with Marriott's mistake. Have stayed in a lot of different hotels for work and have never had a problem. We will not be staying here again.Valet damaged my car but didn't say anything. The hotel tried to check me out two days early even though my confirmation clearly stated the correct check out date. The workout room is extremely dirty. My room had food crumbs on the floor when I checked in. So far, no bedbugs at least.Just a note, I was not compensated for the damage to the car, I was still charged the full valet price!Very nice hotel. I am a fan of Marriott. The lobby looks like it is new. The location could not have been better. You can walk to 30 difference places to eat. Louisville is such a fun town. So i say stay here. You will not be disappointed. Marriott will take care of youA wonderful Marriott Hotel, pretty typical for the most part. They did a good job hosting our conference, with plenty of comfortable rooms to work in. Walls could be a bit thicker between rooms.What I loved best about the Marriott however are:- Loud music in the lobby. Walking off the somewhat boring, wide street into the hotel was like walking into a nightclub by the beach. Loud (but not too loud) dance music, trendy interior, friendly welcome. Cheered me up after a long trip!- SWANS. OMG SWANS. My towels were folded like SWANS in my hotel room *squeeeee* Love. Love. Love. (See photo)Now how can you go wrong with a hotel where your towels are folded into swans?I travel all over the world and this is one of nicest hotels that I've ever stayed in. The rooms are immaculate and well-appointed. The interior design is modern yet warm and welcoming. The beds are so very comfortable. Sometimes I go to Louisville just to spend a weekend in this hotel. If I could move in, I would.This hotel is absolutely gorgeous!! My flight was canceled so I needed a room at the last minute and they came through. Beds are super comfy, decor is fabulous and the staff is very accommodating. I will definitely head to this hotel if I make my way back to Louisville.The rooms were just what I expected from a chain hotel; the carpets looked brand new.The staff was extremely helpful and on top of everything going on. Case in point:I am African American, and "gasp' I arrived in town with my hair undone. I needed to get it done, as my brother was graduating from UofL the very next day. The concierge Leeann Gillbrannock and Andrea Palmer were extremely helpful. They helped me find a place to get my hair done, and it turned out awesome-so that was great. They also helped my mother find everything she needed , in the area, to make my brothers graduation party and event to remember.The atmosphere was very family friendly and they attended to all of my needs. We did have an issue with the wifi, we thought it was free, but it wasn't....the front desk took care of that immediately.Be aware, there is a meretricious sex shop across the street, however, they cant help that...LOL. For some people, this could be a draw. If I was to return, I would definitely pick this hotel.gentrifried.blogspot.comI love this hotel and location. The sports bar right off the lobby offers a great selection of beer, and the prices are decent. Also not too far from Churchhill Downs, which is what brought us to town in the first place.I particularly loved the bedding and pillows, and I'm usually a hard sell on that kind of stuff. I also love that they use Bath and Body Works products and upon returning home, I went right to my local store and purchased the Ginger Citrus lotion that this hotel introduced me to.We will definitely be back.My place in Louisville, when in Louisville. Easy self parking, walk to everything. Good rooms and excellent staff.If you have breakfast in the hotel at Blu make sure you ask for the waitress,,, oh crap I cannot believe I forgot here name. Anyway, she has brown hair, long with only the sides pulled back. Darn Senior Moments!!!! Anyway, she is outstanding.If you do not feel like going out to dinner, Champions is also connected to the place. It is fair, fare. But if you are traveling alone and want a burger, beer, and a game it's right across the hall.Enjoy.One of the better marriott's. Great location, friendly staff, clean rooms. Only downside is parking at $20 a day and no free internet. But excellent gym and very close to 4th street. Stayed two nights last year and one night this year for our bourbon trail weekend. Using Louisville as our hub . Easy to get to traffic wasn't bad, close to freeways and about 45 min to all the bourbon trail attractions. And came back for the city for dinner and drinks. Louisville has a lot to offer, great food hub too.Grand hotel. Good Marriott quality as usual.Only drawback - 22 for self parking (27 for Valet)Welcoming and accommodating staff, clean and modern guest rooms. What more could you ask for. From the moment I arrived to checkout I really felt like a valued guest. Everyone was very friendly and helpful.This is a typical full-service Marriott with a couple restaurants, bars, etc. The workout room was great with plenty of equipment and not too busy. My rrom was recently updated and they were renovating some of the floors below me. Love when a hotel keeps up with the times. As with most Marriotts the rooms are on the smaller side, but they did include a small refrigerator and coffee maker. Hotel room coffe is typically awful, but its great to make Starbucks Via with. And if you really need a triple foam latte there is a full-service Starbucks inside the lobby.In addition to being a very nice hotel it is connected to the convention center.Nice hotel, rooms facing the street are loud. Close to 4th st live. Hotel staff very friendly. Bed was ok not amazing. Shower head in bathroom amazing.Friends were getting married in Louisville, last week, and this was one of the hotels that they'd arranged for a block of rooms to be booked in. It's a pretty standard Marriott. Attentive, friendly staff - though, as typical for most Marriotts, few of them are local or have long spent time in the area, thus not able to really give you a good idea of great, off the beaten path things to do.Appointments were Marriott standard. While the Marriott standard isn't a bad standard, it kinda sucks when you can't tell that you're in any particular Marriott. Used to be, there was more diversity in Marriotts. However, as they standardized their lower tier properties, so have they standardized their marquee hotels. So, this Marriott feels pretty much like every other Marriott you might have stayed in in the last 4-5 years.Room service was speedy if pricey. The downstairs restaurant, Blu, is actually pretty decent. Definitely *several* steps up from the JW steak houses that seem to be present at most of the other Marriotts. The attached bar had a competent staff, knowlegeable in their bourbons and wines and attentive to patrons.Like every other marquee Marriott, they charge you for internet service. If you've got a smart phone or other cell-enabled mobile device, do NOT pay for the internet service. It's so slow that you half expect to hear the screeching chirps of a 1990s analog MODEM. If you've got DSL or better at home or a 3G phone, the speed will be appalling to you. Even watching the concierge struggle with helping us find a movie theatre to go to was painful to watch. Seriously, guys: if you're gonna try to charge me $12.95/day, at least give me enough bandwidth that Google searches aren't slow. Fortunately, Louisville is one of the cities that the major carriers have deployed 4G to. So, I used my cellular data service rather than the joke that the hotel was peddling.
review_content_40: Very nice lobby, good service upon check in, nicely decorated rooms, decent internet, good concierge room.  Not much else to stay, if you have status with Marriott, this is the place to stay in town.I chose this hotel because it was the recommended hotel for the Kentucky Derby Festival Marathon and offered a group rate. The race organizers chose well, overall this is a great property. I can't comment on the hotel's location to the business district, but it is across the street from the Kentucky International Convention Center, near the Yum! Center and a few blocks from Fourth Street Live. The hotel seems to have undergone a recent renovation and houses meeting rooms, a pool and jacuzzi, two restaurants, a bar that serves bourbon flights, and a smaller Starbucks (with habitually long lines). The lobby is quite beautiful, lots of marble, wood and an open airiness. The rooms were nice, clean, well laid out and up-to-date with amenities. On my last morning, we had breakfast at Blu. The breakfast and brunch spreads are quite impressive. For $15.95, I got the breakfast buffet which included hot and cold items, an omelet bar and a choice of juice or coffee. Even if you're not that hungry, the buffets are a sweet deal! I'm a sucker for lox and for $1 more than the menu's lox plate, I was able to enjoy the buffet, which included lox, bagels, all the fixings *plus* a whole slew of other breakfast treats. It's worth noting that the dessert cart for Blu looks amazing too, I wanted to try several items during my stay, but the timing never worked out.There are a few reasons, I can't give this place more than 3.5 stars: 1) My key stopped working one night; rather than waking up my roommate, I went to the front desk. They didn't ask for my name, ID or anything other than the room number to reprogram two keys for me. It's frightening to think that it would be so easy for someone to gain access to my room. 2) The entrance. I hate the automatic revolving door; if someone touches it, it stops. I almost face-planted into it twice when the person ahead of me inadvertently touched it. This is not the time to check your phone or chitchat, unless you like to play russian roulette with your face. The valet also backs up quite easily causing cars to back up into the street at popular times like check in/out and dinner. 3) No exhaust fans in the bathrooms 4) No free wifi, it's $13/day5) Lack of outlets in the room. For an up-to-date room I expect more, well-placed outlets; I've got stuff to charge, yo!I've lived in Louisville all my life and have dealt with most hotels here either as a musical entertainer, guest and lately as a trip advisor contributor.  Saturday, Aug 27, my husband and I celebrated an anniversary with a dinner and night at the Marriott. It was an Ironman weekend and the hotel was busy. The first room they assigned us had no air conditioning. Not wanting to wait for maintenance we agreed to stay in a conference room with a Murphy style (pull down) bed. We snuggled in and rented a movie. My husband got up to get the remote and tripped on a protruding part of the frame which couldn't be seen with the covers down and lights low. Later, barefoot, I got up to use the bathroom and ran into the metal protrusion which sliced my big toenail in half. I bled a lot , had extreme pain and lost 3/4 of my big toenail. The next day, I wrote to The Marriott via their website and told them of the incident and the dangers I saw in that bed. Corporate Marriott wrote me the next day saying the local office would contact me in 3-5 days. It's been 12 days now, even after I wrote a second letter attaching a picture of my mangled and painful toe.  I have yet to decide how to pursue this, but I will caution anyone from booking here based upon this experience. God help the person who may suffer a life threatening injury!!Friendly staff. clean room, great view, amazing location. Worth the weekend trip.Decent, clean, standard Marriott. Rooms have been updated in past 5 years but are getting close to needing some updates. I would stay there again.Another great Marriott property located in the middle of DT Louisville. Gives you walking access to many restaurants and the convention center. Beautiful lobby with a choice of restaurants and bars. The staff is well trained as are most Marriott employees and very helpful and friendly. Rooms are clean, beds comfortable. They do a nice job with groups and meetings. Food service for the masses is very tasty. The hotel is attached to a sports bar with lots of TVs for your viewing pleasure. Typical spots bar (average) food. The only negative is the parking garage fees. Pricey. Overall with room and taxes you are in for $230 per night unless you grab a special deal.I have stayed at my fair share of Marriot properties and, this one ranks as one of the best. Located conveniently in downtown it is minutes to most destinations. The rooms are spacious and well-kept and the lobby is welcoming. I found the service to be very helpful almost to the point of doting. This is appreciated, I believe, as it is always nice to be treated as important. The concierge lounge is comfortable and well-appointed with a wonderful view. I would rank this as my go-to Marriott in the greater Louisville area, likely staying here for anything I needed to do within a 45 minute drive.Great hotel in a great downtown Louisville location.This Marriott is within walking distance to both the KFC Yum! Center and the Fourth Street entertainment district. Don't feel like venturing out? There are two bars, a restaurant and a Starbucks in the lobby.The workout facilities are stellar with several treadmills to get your sweat on. Conference facilities are also well laid-out and roomy.Not that I've ever slept on a marshmallow, but if I did, I'm sure it would feel like the Marriott beds. Our room had a great view of the skyline, and walking around felt pretty safe. The staff was gracious and helpful, and also well prepared with local information.There is a Starbucks in the lobby for a quick caffeine fix, and a cool loungy area with an extensive Kentucky bourbon selection.I tried out the fitness room, which was clean and well maintained. They supplied towels and a water cooler, as well as tvs to watch.The little extras that make this place a joy to stay.  The cucumber lemon water / grapefruit cranberry water in the lobby is just refreshing. There is always a nice, fresh, crisp smell when you walk into the lobby :)I never once had to wait for someone to assist me.  In fact, there were several attendants always waiting to assist someone in the lobby.  I have never seen anything like it.  Everyone, from the front desk staff, housekeeping, bell men, concierge were very helpful and friendly.A Starbuck's, Champion's sports restaurant and BLU Mediterranean restaurant is downstairs as well.  The hotel is attached to the Louisville city walk, so you can walk to the Hyatt next door, the convention center, and several other places without going outside.  Valet parking seems too expensive to me.  It's $16 0-4 hours, and $25 for anything more.  I did not have a car this trip, so I'm not sure of self parking rates.The rooms are what you would expect from a Marriott, and the bed. . . OMG!!! the bed.  It's like sinking into billowy clouds. . .very comforting and snugly.  The room also has a refrigerator, a microwave would be nice, however, I did not ask for one.  I like the easy check out using the TV as well.  Will definitely make a point to return when I'm in town!Such wonderful accommodation! Friendly and helpful staff! The room was bigger than my house haha! SSooooo epic!!!Enjoyed a recent 5 day  vacation stay at this excellent downtown hotel located within walking distance of many restaurants, pubs, etc.  Upgraded attractive lobby and rooms with personnel always available to answer questions.  Be aware, that this Marriott doesn't have a shuttle service to/from the airport.  Although the nearby Marriott Courtyard does offer a shuttle, guests at the Marriott Downtown cannot use it.  For those of us not on an expense account, that's an extra $40 round trip for a cab.Just another excellent Marriott hotel - not that I'm biased.This place is basically my second home.  I roll in Monday afternoon every week after work, and the friendly staff instantly recognizes me, pulls out my weekend bag, assigns me a decent room on the concierge floor, and send me on my way!  House keeping is always up to par too.And there are all kinds of great little extras. A Starbucks downstairs next to the desk so I can grab my coffee on the way to the office.  Flavored water in the afternoons.  Updated gym facility.  Thanks to my extended family at the Marriott!Excellent Marriott located in downtown Louisville. Walking distance to just about anythign you would need to do in town. Concierge lounge is large on one of the highest floors and has a great view. The attendant in the lounge told me they did not have Verses on thier cable systme, but there is a sports bar locate din the lobby....which sure enough, there is! Had wonderful service at the bar including no problem getting Verses for the Flyers/ Penguins game. As a Flyers fan, I sat next to a guy who came over from the Hampton Inn, was a Penguins fan, and was told this sports bar would have the game. Had a wonderful meatloaf w/ mashed potatoes dinner (it was about 10 degrees outside, needed some comfort food) while watching the game. Would recommend this propertry to anyone traveling into Louisville for biz or pleasure.Yes, of course, the Flyers won the game.If you can figure out the layout of the rooms before you look for your meeting, then you are a step ahead of the game.  Very well-kept Marriott Property.  I did hate that the startbucks charges $6.75 for a muffin and iced grande; whereas my Los Angeles one charges $5.40 for the exact same thing.  That bugs me!

review_content: Best Brunch in Louisville! I am never, ever disappointed. Tables and tables of endless food, including mounds of crab claws and fresh shrimp, lox...an array of hearty local cheeses and loads of hot options.I recently enjoyed a moroccan style pork loin with couscous, it was amazing. The waffle station and omelets to order are a nice touch, with an overwhelming array of other traditional breakfast items--sausage, bacon, rolls and muffins. The desserts are plentiful and range from house-made toffee to deep, dark chocolate mousse, derby pie, tarts and plates of cookies and truffles, Whew!Free cocktail! A glass of complimentary champagne or a mimosa is my fave part, best to order two. Enjoy, be sure to call for a reservation, also they stop the seating at 2:30, the buffet ends at 3PM unless it is a special holiday.Stroll along the mezzanine and take in the lavish lobby and stunning antiques, close your eyes and dream of the gilded age and life during another era and time...guests have enjoyed the Seelbach for many generations and it is still fantastic. Bon Appetit!Stayed here for one night in May 2014, travelling with family. The hotel is very opulent - the lobby is an art deco dream and the Rookwood pottery room downstairs a sight to behold.The service though was pretty shoddy - we arrived in the middle of a torrential downpour - valet parking guy came with his umbrella to ask if we were parking, which was fairly obvious. He then disappeared, leaving us and our luggage to get absolutely soaked. He didn't fill in our valet ticket either, which meant his colleagues had to search for our car for some time when we left.We stayed on the top floor, our room was spacious and clean. Very high ceilings. Bathroom was nice, but lacked space to put anything down in. The bed though was fabulous, very comfortable. Access to the executive lounge was great, free drinks and canapes and an honesty bar for spirits. The hotel comped us breakfast after our poor welcome - buffet style in the Gatsby breakfast room, it was plentiful and tasty, with omelettes made to order by a friendly chef. The bar has a massive selection of bourbons which pleased my partner, as we were heading off on the bourbon trail afterwards. The bar isn't as swish as you'd think from the rest of the hotel though.The hotel is situated right next to main street live area which is good for bars on a saturday night. the microbrewery on the corner of the main street live block was good.All in all, I'd stay there again, just for the bed - so comfortable!Having spent a weekend in Louisville at this hotel I think I can give you some helpful info for your visit. First, if you're going to a wedding in this hotel - definitely stay in the hotel. Max convenience. It's very old. Like featured in the Great Gatsby old. (Not a joke - they are proud of it.) Anyway the rooms show the age, but they do meet Hilton standards. Barely. Note: some rooms have an extremely loud cooling and heating system so maybe have a listen before you get too settled. Gym - it's got the same two generations old Precor machines my 24 Hour Fitness has. But it has a gym and it does have 4-5 of every basic kind of equipment as well as a cold water dispenser. The seventh floor has a cooler full of free bottled water and soda. From what I can tell you have to pay cash money to a vending machine on the other floors. The Old Seelbach Bar makes some great drinks! Our server informed us the "Minted Gold," a take on the classic Kentucky Derby cocktail, recently won some national cocktail competition. It was good but probably not that good. Warning: They've done some pretty bad things with the interior decor (best description is Courtyard Marriott furniture and a bunch of sports TVs installed in an otherwise beautiful and historic space).The room (a bookable event space) in the basement is cool. Check it out. The hotel itself is pretty well located for most things in downtown Louisville. Things that seem like a far walk on the map are usually a maximum 15 minutes away.I unfortunately cannot rate the rooms or any of the amenities that this hotel has to offer, I am basing this off of the rooms I have been to for two different events held here. So living in the Louisville area I had not officially been to The Seelbach until last week. I know, sad considering the history of this building and how beautiful it is!On Thursday I won tickets to go to "Your Maker's Makers Louisville" in the Rathskeller. The event simply would not have had the same effect had it been anywhere else. Walking into this room you are taken back to the 20's. There is intricate designs on the ceilings, walls and floor. The room is breath taking. The bar is gorgeous as well with hard wood and a very unique backdrop. The acoustics in the room are amazing and while talking to some other people at the event I learned that back in the 80's (for a short time) they did some concerts down there and I would have done just about anything to be there for those. There is not a single drop of modern in this room and I. Love. It! If you've never been down here then I encourage to take the trip and just prepare for the architectural shock that you're getting ready to experience. The second time I got to visit was for Louisville SWIG. It (unfortunately, but fortunately) was not held in the Rathskeller as that room would have been way too small to hold all those people. So SWIG was held in the ballroom, which was still a little packed as there were a lot of vendors and people dancing and having a blast. The room also gives that prohibition feel to it and has amazing ambiance and acoustics as well. The live music carried throughout the whole room and there was a decent sized dance floor laid out in the middle. The whole hotel, from the outside to the inside reads history, glamour and Louisville. I'm super impressed and if I ever want to have a staycation in downtown I know where I'm rooming!I've never stayed at the Seelbach Hilton. So, I can't review the rooms, or what any other aspect of staying there as an actual guest is like. However, I do park my car in their garage, and I have for the past four years, so I walk through the hotel twice a day most days. And I've gotta say, the hotel is very nice. It has a very pre-repeal of prohibition feel to it, which is fun. They renovated a few things a couple of years ago, and they put in new carpet, etc. to give (at least parts of) the hotel a more modern feel. In addition to the main part of the hotel I have also been to several other spaces in the Seelbach. One of those spaces is the Old Seelbach Bar. I visited the bar before it's renovation, and I really enjoyed it. The cocktails were good, there was a nice wine selection, and again the space is beautiful. I've also been to the smaller restaurant downstairs, Gatsby's on Fourth (previously Otto's), and it's a great lunch spot. They have a pretty good buffet and several reasonably priced menu items for a quick lunch. And there's a Starbucks in the building as well, so that's convenient.  I've also attended events in both the Rathskeller and the grand ballroom. Both spaces are awesome. The grand ballroom is great for larger events, or weddings. And the Rathskeller is really cool. It's located in the basement and is completely decorated in Rookwood pottery. It apparently used to be a restaurant, but now it's only used occasionally for private events. The decor is awesome and when you're in the Rathskeller you feel like you're in a speakeasy during the Roaring 20's. I highly recommend taking a trip down there if given the chance. Overall, as a spot to eat, grab a drink, attend an event, or just go look at I would definitely recommend the Seelbach Hilton.Gorgeous historical hotel.  The lobby is gorgeous with preserved wood detail in the ceilings and walls.  Gilded mouldings and marble detail speak of yesteryear.  The murals that surround the foyer area are faded but perceptible.  There is one of George Washington.  The original bookcase behind the reception area deserves a good look.  I did not stay here so I can't comment on the rooms but I imagine they are gorgeous too.Historic hotel. A true landmark in Louisville. They have done a remarkable job trying to keep the original look of an elegant hotel from the 1900's. Rooms are small but very comfortable. Their beds and pillows are heavenly. I normally preferred newer hotels, but I loved the 5 days I spent at this hotels. Their lobby is a masterpiece!!! If you are in Louisville, definitely go check it out. You will fee like Al Capone!A stunningly beautiful historic hotel in downtown Louisville!  From the moment you step inside, you will be in awe of the amazing historic decor.  Our room was perfect and the bed was very comfortable.Every staff member we encountered was very friendly from the valet to the bellman to the front desk.  We did get bad information from the concierge on the actual time Churchill Downs opened which did not make us too happy because we got there an hour after they opened and we were short on time.We would definitely stay here again the next time we are in Louisville.my experience here went from bad to worse with the discovery that this hotel apparently has a roach infestation. the largest roach I have ever seen paraded his way into my room (under the wide gap at the bottom of the door) on day 2. someone from maintenance came up and took care of that issue, but then I saw another dead roach in the corner of my room. he had obviously been there for some time and housekeeping just never bothered to vacuum it up.  also on day 3 housekeeping barged into my room even though my privacy sign was out (response was - uh sorry. we thought you checked out. but we made a mistake on the room number).  many many other issues with the room and this property in general. it is the most dismal property I have ever stayed at.  never again!This is a classic old hotel in downtown Louisville.  As an old hotel, the rooms are somewhat small when compared to the newer but more antiseptic hotels found in the suburbs.  This is a Hilton hotel and Hilton has done a marvelous job of retaining the historic character of the old hotel and of making it a very comfortable place to stay. The size of the rooms aside, the rooms were extremely comfortable with super comfortable beds and beautiful decor.  All of the staff was quite helpful -- starting with the parking valet, the doorman and the front desk.  All of them seemed eager to be helpful and I didn't encounter any staff members who displayed any kind of a negative attitude.  If you're looking for a large, generic room -- book something out in the suburbs.  If you're looking for a very nice, very historic downtown location, this is a great hotel and I would highly recommend it.GORGEOUS property.  Hilton. Enough said. . Location is downtown which is ok though I don't believe the parking valets were prepared for a law firm retreat this past weekend.  Very unorganized and just too hard on the parking staff. Felt bad for them.  Front desk team rocked.  Saw we were diamond members and quickly put us on the honors floor.   The food/beverage staff in our breakfast and lunch room were perfect. Considering it was a large event the food as really good. I usually manage my expectations with a big crowd.  This place did a nice job .  The fitness center was awesome.  Starbucks on the first floor which was perfect.  CVS across the street which is always a relief when traveling in case one needs last minute items. Tried venturing out on Saturday and its best to stick to the 4th street commercial area.  Anything outside of that isn't much of a desirable area.The rooms run cold. Take layers.  Our room had a safe in the closet - SCORE.   I love that.  The shower pressure was amazing.  Bed was comfy.  We'd go back.The hotel is beautiful and the staff is very friendly and accommodating. The room was clean, but they forgot to put shampoo and conditioner in my room, so I had to call the front desk to get some. Because it is an older building, noise travels through the doors and walls. I could very clearly hear every word from the tv in the neighboring room until it was turned off at midnight. I could even hear my neighbor put the remote down on the bedside table! I could hear doors opening and closing in the hall, as well as people talking and walking. Eventually, I turned on white noise so I could sleep. Stay on the concierge floor (7th) if possible!This hotel is AMAZING. If you love a historical feel, and a good ghost story, along with BEAUTIFUL architecture.... then this place is for you. From the moment we pulled up, i knew i'd love this place. It's just beautiful!  Both the Valet and Bell Hop guys were ready and waiting the minute we pulled up to the front! The down-side, valet was super expensive ($27). I'm from Chicago, and that's about what they charge downtown - I certainly don't expect that in Louisville, KY. My mouth hit the floor when I walked into the Lobby. The old-world charm,and grandeur of it!! The Room: I was kinda heebed out walking barefoot, the carpet felt a little greasy. But the room itself was nice enough. Somewhat basic, but nice amenities. The bathroom was pretty, beautiful sink and large tub, although hardly any counter-space. The beds, like most Hilton properties, was amazing. Super comfy- and the linens were soft. Very nice.  Since the person I was staying with was an Honors member, we stayed on the 8th floor, and were able to partake in the morning breakfast, which was nice.For the price you pay, each room should definitely have it's own mini-fridge. Hands-down. Quite an annoyance, as it's become the standard across most hotels. What really made the stay here lovely was the service. Every single person we interacted with was super-friendly and very helpful. They really score an A++ on the Customer Service. From the valet, to the bell-hop, to the front-desk folks, etc etc.. everyone was sooo nice!! Definitely take some time to explore the hotel, and ask the front-desk for the little history-packet they have. Definitely check out the Oak Room, The Bar, and The Rathskeller.  Part of the Great Gatsby was written here, Al Capone used to hang here, a woman killed herself here in the 30's (?) and is now "claimed" to occasionally "visit". SO much history - it's awesome!! Now, the individual rooms may not be as super-fancy as some Hilton's, but what it lacks in that area (minorly) it makes up for in history and architecture and ambiance. I would totally stay here over a typical "fancy" hotel any day. It just made my heart happy. I guess you could say i was totally geekin'-out over this place.What a beautiful historic hotel!Check in: easy,  breezyRoom: quaint, clean, and comfortable. Reminds me of the Drake hotel of Chicago sans gold trims and accents. I stayed on the concierge floor, so the room also came with a couple of plush robes and 24-hr access to the business center on the floor and refreshments refrigerator stocked with water and soda. I will definitely be going back!I recently stayed here for a professional conference. It's an old world hotel that is now part of the Hilton chain. The rooms are all a little different in shape and set up but generally smaller than what you might expect. My room was clean enough, but it  was never made up earlier than 4 pm. Generally, the staff here is not what you'd expect from a Hilton property. The desk staff in particular are understaffed at check in and out, and when we asked them to split the bill for myself and my colleague who was sharing my room, they were happy to do so, but seemed bewildered at getting it done, and it took two tries! (I should mention I was not the only one who had trouble with that). Its well located, but if I go back to Louisville, I'll look to the Brown Hotel as an option.I live in Louisville and don't often find a reason to say in any of the historic hotels downtown, but on New Years Eve my boyfriend and I attended a wedding and said "why not?!" I've always wanted to stay in the Seelbach and the lobby/entry way is as grand as I imagined but I was extremely underwhelmed by the size of the room/bathroom but everything was clean and surprisingly quiet considering it was New Year's Eve. I was the most disappointed to find that the hotel charges valet parking for each individual day (30 dollars a day) despite us only being there one night and checking out on time. My one piece of advice would be to park on the street and if you are looking for a spacious room, look elsewhere!I can see why this hotel is so pricey to stay in! This is by far THE fanciest hotel I've ever stayed in!Despite living near Louisville, I opted to stay at the Seelbach on March 4th this year before snowmaggedon hit. I work at Kosair Children's Hospital (KCH) and nurses don't get snowdays. Instead of trying to commute to work, I decided to "rough it" at the Hilton instead!I parked in front of the building and was greeted by a valet. For an additional $4/night the valet parked my car for me. I came inside, got a room key and went up to my room. This place is NICE on the inside! I believe this hotel had to be used in the most recent Gatsby movie because the decor seemed familiar. Anyways, once I made it up to my room (I got the double beds room because it's cheaper) I made a bee line for the tolietries. I had to call the front desk for more tolietries because they're all Peter Thomas Roth brand (hello! ) so I just had to have more!!  After that I went to work out in their fitness facility, which is much nicer than any gym I've been to in a hotel! They had several cardio machines, some free weights, a few weight machines, some yoga mats... I mean seriously I doing to pay money to be a gym member there! so I worked up a good sweat, took a nice long hot shower and ordered some room service.I regret not taking a photo of the food or see it with room service because it was so delicious! I ordered a Gatsby burger with no bun add bacon and cheese, with sweet potato fries, a glass of wine, a Side of cauliflower gratin, and some chocolate gelato for desert. The cauliflower gratin was so creamy, Rich, and the cauliflower itself was just the perfect amount of crunchy to it! The portion was gigantic! I really could've made a meal out of it to be honest, but since I just worked out I was ravenous. The burger was cooked perfectly to how I ordered it, the sweet potato fries were light and crisp. I loved the little Heinz glass bottles of ketchup and mayonnaise that came with my meal too! So cute! The chocolate gelato was easily the best chocolate gelato I've ever eaten! It was super creamy, had big chunks of dark chocolate inside, and the portion was way too much, but obviously I ate it all  The glass of white Zinfandel was a perfect touch with my bubble bath but I enjoyed it with my Peter Thomas Roth bath products.Of course the most important part of staying at a hotel is the sleep you get. I didn't hear anything going on in the hallways, so they must do a pretty good job of insulating the walls. The pillows and bedding are so comfortable, therefore, I am looking into getting some pillows from the Hilton website. I believe these pillows are about $80 a piece. A good night sleep to me is worth all the money in the world!When it came time to make the 1.5 mile commute to work the next day, the roads were covered in snow! Thankfully for me, the valet safely got my card to me and I was able to make it to work on time and in one piece. The next time I have to work at the hospital and there's an impending storm coming, I am definitely going to stay at the Seelbach again!Absolutely beautiful hotel , stupendous service with a great restaurant ( The Oak Room) & a nice bar. The drinks in the bar are short, and service is very slow, though the atmosphere is nice.It loses a star , because the room was very small. Beautiful, just too small.Smallest rooms in the world. Not of any Hilton standards that I am aware of..... silly not true BS marketing hotel website made me believe this is an upscale special hotel in louisville.  Come on..... what a joke . This is an old outdated hotel. Nothing special here. I feel like a fool for telling my wife it is a wonderful hotel to stay at.....OMG.My wife tells me I'm being hard on the hotel. Well... it is overall sharp looking in the lobby and the staff is very friendly.We booked this hotel for our wedding anniversary weekend and was really looking forward to our trip.  The interior of the hotel such as the lobby and the common rooms are beautiful, the staff was attentive and courteous and there is a Starbucks right on the property.  We did not eat in either restaurant however we did have room service from Gatsbys for our breakfast which was mediocre and they forgot something each time; however it was prompt within the time frame, the food warm.  Our only real complaint is the rooms.  We were upgraded to a junior suite however the room was musty, the furnishings worn and the bathroom was not functioning properly.  The toilet wouldn't flush properly and the hot water took minutes to arrive making me wonder if it was broken, however, when it did show up, it was fine.  A staff room was right next door and we could hear them talking to one another at all hours of the day through a vent.  Our upgrade was more a downgrade.We moved to a regular room the next day which was a bit better., more open and less cramped but with the same tired, scratched furnishings, decor, peeling wallpaper (repaired but obvious)  and cracked lamp shades.  The rooms weren't as clean as I expect from this type of hotel.  A Hampton Inn would have been more comfortable and the breakfast offered would been on the same scale as the food we received at the Seelbach, a significant difference in room prices.  The hotel is conveniently located to 4th Street Live and we were able to walk to our restaurants, etc.  The valet was quick and courteous.  Overall, if our rooms had been updated, fresher and cleaner where we felt more comfortable I would have returned to this hotel but I'm afraid we will choose differently the next time we come to Louisville.
review_content_20: Sure, the Seelbach Hotel was something special in its heyday... 50 years ago. Now it's just a dated, overpriced hotel that is living off its storied past.If you opt to self-park ($18 overnight), the garage entrace is on Muhammad Ali Blvd. DON'T blink or you'll miss it. DON'T follow the signs for "Rear Hotel Entrance" up to the 6th level or you'll find out the hard way it was for nothing. Park on the lower level and take the elevator to the ground floor. Entrance to the hotel is across the alley way.The lobby is nice -- ample gathering space and the front desk agents are friendly and helpful. There's the renowned Seelbach Bar and the Oak Room, great options when you consider what other hotels have to offer. I had a room on the 9th floor and MAN, THIS ROOM HAS SEEN BETTER DAYS. There are chips and dings all over the doors and walls, dripping shower, yellow stains on the tub, period stain on the desk chair.... should I keep going? The bathroom is TINNNNNYYY. I'm no KG, but I'm pretty sure my 5'4" wingspan can touch the door and tub at the same time.The saving grace of this hotel is the SOLE FACT that it is across the street from 4th Street and a handy CVS for those little items that you left at home.Before the 21C hotel was created in Louisville, there were 2 grand hotels that were built in the early 20th century: The Brown, and The Seelbach. Up until the last weekend, I had only stayed at The Brown.I was in Louisville for the weekend, and I had some Hilton points to burn. Since the Seelbach is operated by yup, you guessed it- Hilton, I decided to give it a shot. Opened in 1905, the Seelbach is a gem to the city of Louisville with a lot to offer.I drove, but I didn't feel like valet (which is on the 4th St entrance), I took the deck- be careful and keep an eye open, as the deck comes up quickly on your left (don't worry, if you miss it, you can go back around the block). Look for pedestrians, as it is kind of narrow.There is a back entry to the hotel, with 2 automated doors. You walk through some conference areas (or "salons"), and then approach the lobby. The lobby is kind of small, but packs a punch. Its dark woods, pretty carpentry, and marble fit it appropriately.Check in kind of took a bit, and it was weird, as the area is tight, so when you stand in line and people are sitting in the chairs, your junk gets up close and personal with random people. Definitely cozy here, throughout (keep that in mind) the hotel.Apparently, there were 2 weddings at the hotel that evening. They must have thought I was part of one of them, as they put me with one of the parties. Hmm.. However, with my Gold Status, I got free club access, which came in handy for pregaming.Out of 10 floors, I was on the 4th, in 424. It was one of the larger standard rooms, but it still had that cozy feel. The appointments were old school, and it was nice it had an air purifier in the room (not sure if it was a PURE allergy room or not). When I went to the restroom- it was nice- but honestly- I have seen more room in a porter potty! You could literally shave and take a crap at the same time- maybe their intention was the invention of multi-tasking?The water pressure in the shower was alright, and took a minute to warm up, but be careful, because when it gets hot, it rips! Also, there are "oh-shit!" bars in the shower for a reason- if you are using the house soap, USE THE BAR when washing your feet- it gets slippery!!! When I ventured up to the club level to pregame, I took the elevator to the 7th floor (key card req). There was not a sign to the club, so I just walked the whole floor (I didn't look like a creepster, at all!) until the path dead ended into it. It was small and filled with a bunch of dudes, but I was just there to get some booze. They had beer, a small selection of liquor, some snacks, sodas, and juices. It was relaxing. They also serve breakfast in the morning there, but I forgot to get it.When I came back to the hotel later that evening, I decided to get some room service (which is 24 hours). I ordered a cobb salad and a turkey club- noticed how I ordered a cobb? When the gentleman came, he had brought me a turkey club and a caesar salad. I wanted something different that night, but they must have known of my munchies and my love for caesars. But still, they got it wrong!I slept well that evening- that bed was extremely comfortable. It was nice, after a long week. Room service kept knocking on my door at the ass crack of dawn (should have put up the thing on the doorknob)- keeping me awake. I could have used the extra hour or 2 of sleep.I went downstairs to the giftshop, and bought some goodies. This place is definitely unique in many ways, and have suites here that you will not find anywhere else- be sure to ask about them! Also, in the basement, they have the Rathskeller- the only surviving room made of pottery and leather in the world! Be sure to check that out. However, if you need your space, this place is probably not for you...I was in town for a conference at another hotel, but stayed here. So, I did not get to eat at the Seelbach or drink in the bar.This is an interesting historic hotel, with all of the cool stuff and all of the baggage that comes with that type of place. Everything is old, but in good condition. It is very interesting to look at, and I like the old time feel.The elevators are small, and fact many of the doors are small. A lot of the fixtures are old, but functional.My room was modern enough, and a decent size. The bathroom was quite modern, although there was virtually no bathroom counter space. Even sitting on the toilet is a bit cramped between the sink and the wall...The bed was comfortable, the A/C worked very well, and everything was quiet.All in all, I had a pleasant stay. The location is great -- just steps from the very popular "Fourth Street Live" area. The hotel even offers a free shuttle to and from the airport, which is a nice touch.I had a great stay and would definitely return.I had a wonderful stay at this hotel. They were extremely accommodating, from the valet, to the bellhop assisting me with bags to and from the room, to the front desk allowing for a very late checkout time (I was getting married the next day & needed the room in the AM to get ready) to the hassle free checkout. I am a Hilton Honors member, and I will definitely return for a longer stay ass soon as possible. The history behind the hotel is intriguing and I loved that the old doors are still used, and the old mail "tunnels" are still in tact. The room was much larger than I anticipated which was a pleasant surprise as well. My only complaint is the pricey breakfast ($50 + for 2 orders of French toast & an eggs Benedict).Being from Louisville, I get the whole Seelbach nostalgia thing. It is nice. The front desk staff however is NOT. First, they need more staff. This is not a boutique hotel in the French Quarter with 20 rooms where you can get away with one snarky/evil little troll who thinks she is the Queen of Everything including appointing herself your Time Master. While she was busy flirting with the married man (Hellooo honey, look at the ring finger! Notice anything? Of course not because you are different and morals must not apply to you!) I was left standing and waiting for attention. After several minutes (and I am a very patient person normally. I mean really, we aren't standing in bread lines in this country people so be grateful and try to relax and wait. At least that is USUALLY my motto!) I finally spoke up and asked for her to pass me something. She said in a very nasty tone that she would be with me in just one moment. Of course that was several more minutes. I asked her what took her about 15 seconds to complete and walked away. I know I totally put her out but hey, I thought she could take a moment to be a helpful employee of her company. So that is my rant on the nasty girl at the front desk. As far as the room is concerned, it is a postage stamp and if you stay on the second floor good luck figuring out where you are going. Even the bell-hop was confused. (That part was actually comical and made me chuckle ;) ) Way too small to pay $179 + taxes and fees for a night. It is kind of convenient but you are by the tourist draw of 4th Street Live. Go check out NuLu, it is way cooler with better food and drink. This would never be my first choice of hotel in Louisville.Patrick took us on a late night tour to the basement and it was incredible! He's the man!Creepy and outdated are two words for this hotel. It's very small and the bathroom is awkward. Bad experience here my first time as there were a few maintenance issues that I didn't appreciate. I was put on the so called "haunted floor (8th)". Things like that do not worry me at all but I was a little shaken so I requested I be put on another floor. The front desk personnel were very nice but I would prefer not to stay at this hotel ever again. I'm a big fan of the hilton franchise but would gladly stay at the Marriott close by. This hotel is a one time thing but for the price tag, I prefer a hotel with up to date designs and furniture.Stayed here the weekend of Forecastle Festival. Nightly rate for queen ~$300. This is not a $300/night hotel. This feels more like a $129/night hotel, and if you are lucky enough to get that rate you are likely to be happier than I was. Seems like the rates jump wildly -- a fellow festival-goer got a last minute $120/night deal. Boy do I feel like a chump! The common areas of the hotel are stupefyingly beautiful and the service is great. Do visit the Rathskeller in the basement. The rooms, however, left a lot to be desired. The quality of toilet paper and tissues equaled what you'd find at a truck stop. No mini fridge. Shower took 10 minutes to get warm. Wallpaper was worn and torn. Bathroom grout was black in areas from years of wear. Toilet ran and ran and ran when flushed and only excessive jiggling of the handle shut it up. Regarding useable bathroom space, there is ZERO counter space and NO hook to hang a toiletries bag. Initially, I didn't think this would be a problem because there's a small shelf above the toilet. But the shelf is full of hotel junk and not easily accessible in relation to electrical outlets. There is also no mirror near an outlet in the bedroom. Using a flat iron required placing the iron in the sink when I needed to put it down, and placing my brush and hairspray on the toilet lid. There is space between the sink and toilet for a table; it would be nice if the hotel provided one. It would also be awesome if they ponied up for some Charmin and Kleenex.I disliked this hotel for many reasons.1. Parking... if you do not valet park, call ahead and get directions to their secret garage. Oh, it's $22 per night to park in the secret garage too. Was the garage easy to find? No. 2. 8th Floor room 681 was my room. You can hear everything coming down the hall way. The door, while it looks cool, allows all conversations and housekeeping to echo right into the room. 3. I've had roomier showers in an RV camping.4. $149 +tax, $22 for parking and I would have had to pay for WiFi. No. This place is not worth it whatsoever.Once you get pasted the complaints, the bed was comfortable, the shower had great pressure and the AC unit worked well.Is this worth $149 per night. No!I like this hotel, but it has its shortcomings. I think it's riding on its historic charm, great location, and the like. I think customer service is a little lacking though. I showed up at 2 in the morning, and was notified that I was being walked to the Hyatt. Annoying at that time of night. They were nice about it , and so was I.Then, the next day, I had to check out of the Hyatt by noon, and check into the Hilton. My room wasn't ready. Annoying, but I was nice about it. I checked my bags with the bellman, and went to Churchill Downs to bet on the ponies. When I returned, they had upgraded me to a queen junior suite. Nice! My bill was slipped under my door on the morning of my checkout. My room rate was double what my company had negotiated. Unacceptable. They fixed it, but the whole experience was a pain. Good property, just failed me a number of times on this visit.Stayed here this past Saturday night. Very convenient to fourth st live and good location. Half of Louisville is under construction though not there fault, husband is hilton diamond and when we checked in we were assigned a room without an upgrade. We called down and Katie offered to move us and meet us with the new keys. Seriously we needed to ask to be upgraded? Ok but new room was nice. Had lounge closed so instead offered us a coupon each for a drink and the. One coupon for an appetizer to share. The lounge was closed since occupancy was low. We went to the Rathskeller to use the coupons. They allowed you to pay a charge to upgrade the liquor choice which my husband did for $3. The appetizer was six pieces of chicken wings or three each. The menu said regular price was $10. That's ridiculous. They were decent but smidgen undercooked and not worth the price if we paid for them. Breakfast was nice and coupons said continental but Armondo our server advised for all items and offered eggs fresh from the kitchen. We chose to have an omelet which was really good. The decor is very pretty. The staircase and lobby very grand. The rooms have strange layouts because older but a very nice place to be. I would stay again but maybe when hotel and area are busier. Still nice grand dameWe stayed at two different Hiltons while honeymooning and this one was by far the worst! The room was old and stunk like a old ashtray. We walked in and thought the person who stayed before us must have been smoking in the room and after two full days it still stunk! Not that I'm looking for free goodies but no one even acknowledged it was our honeymoon and then charged us $15 for a hotel guest(me his wife!) we had to pay for wifi which should just be standard or built into the rate. Overall we are really disappointed with the room and lack of service. Location is the only good part about this place.Stayed here for 1 night during a recent trip to Kentucky/Tennessee. A colleague booked us here and I'm glad he did. Some highlights of my brief stay:+ The bar at the hotel has awesome Beer on tap, served in frozen glasses, yum!yelp.com/biz_photos/0E_Y...+ The hotel has an older "historical" feel to it...I don't know the history of the hotel, but it gave me the same historical feeling that I get when I'm at Wrigley Field.yelp.com/biz_photos/0E_Y...+ Rooms were well appointed and beds were super comfortable.yelp.com/biz_photos/0E_Y...+ Every employee, from the valet guy to the front desk, was extremely helpful and friendly.Overall, it was an awesome stay despite being so brief. If I return to Louisville, this place will be on my list.Return Factor - 90%Beautiful hotel. Very charming and historic. Clean rooms. Beautiful decor. Excellent location!! We loved our stay at Steelbuch, it was exceptional. The only reason I took one star off is because they don't have free wifi. Also, Parking was bit pricey..Cool colonial style modernized hotel with great food and service. my room, sadly seemed to have a heater as loud as a diesel generatorHave a much greater appreciation of the hotel now that I have had the ghost tour. Ask for it, it's amazing! The shuttle service is great because you can ask for rides to places other than the airport. For example, we got a ride to Mayan Cafe which saved us a huge walk. The concierge lounge is cool as well, and the staff is very helpful and accommodating. I still would rather have a large bathroom with counter space (definitely not for girls like me who travel with tons of toiletries), but it's a nice stay.My husband took me here as a birthday surprise and it was FANTASTIC!! It's old and beautiful and sophisticated and opulent and classy! They treat you so well there and are so warm. We had drinks at the Old Seelbach Bar, they were delicious, cold and fairly priced. I also love the history of the hotel, so many fun facts! We've decided to make it a tradition and I can't wait to go back next year and for many more to come!This is a beautiful property, rich with history and atmosphere. I wanted to move in once I saw the gorgeous suite they gave us for our stay. The concierge lounge was nice, the staff helpful and friendly, and the resident ghost gave us no trouble at all. Make sure to check out the little room off of the Oak Room restaurant on the mezzanine level, where Al Capone played cards and made his getaways through the secret passageway. If you like ghost stories make sure to talk to John, a 30 year veteran of the hotel, who has also written a book about the woman who died here and still roams the halls. Fun stuff!With all of the history and uniqueness, what really set this place apart is the customer service! Second to none - every request (from a mini fridge being brought up to the room to a 4 a.m. pizza delivery) was handled with a gracious smile. Early and late check-in requests were honored, and the staff even dropped off some complimentary deserts. You get what you pay for - the Seelbach is more expensive than other hotels, but not by much. The extra $20/night we spent over the standard chains down the street was beyond worth it for the experience.The Seelbach is in a great location for exploring Louisville. Stayed here on a girls' weekend trip to the Forecastle music festival and this hotel is now in my top 5 of all time. The rooms were on the small side and offered nice furnishings, a large bathroom, and the most glorious pillows I've ever slept on in a hotel room. Historic touches like the wooden doors with a box to leave your dry cleaning out and the original post office boxes are cute details. The lobby and Seelbach bar are gorgeous. Go downstairs to the Rathskeller and take pictures - and do so on the staircase as well! The only downsides were: Paid WiFi (this is 2014 so I just think that's tacky)The room could have used a second mirrorThis historic hotel has a great history. Although the lobby is not as elegant as some historic hotels, it is still gorgeous with its painted murals of old Kentucky scenes. We learned that in the 1960s the murals were covered up in an effort to modernize the look of the hotel and rediscovered when the hotel was renovated. If you go, if even for a drink in the Old Seelbach Bar, don't miss the Rathskeller on the lower level. When it was built in the early 1900s, it was decorated completely with Rookwood Pottery (from Cincinnati)--floors, walls, ceiling--everything. It appears it is only used for private parties now. Like many historic hotels, the guest rooms are small. Elevators are quite tight here as well.
review_content_40: I love this hotel.  It's beautiful and the staff was really great.  The breakfast was good.  I think it's much better at the Hilton Tyson's Corner in VA which is my benchmark or I would have given this property 5 stars.  The concierge lounge was just ok as well.  This is all really nit picking as this is an historic and fabulous place to stay if you are ever in Louisville.Stayed at the Seelbach this past weekend.  Fantastic historical hotel.  Staff was exceptional.  My only word of caution... We used the valet service for our stay.  Dropped off Friday morning.  Saturday called to have car brought down and the low tire pressure light was on.  We didn't drop it off like that.  8lbs low pressure. We filled while out.  Checked out Sunday and luckily got home before we had a flat tire.  There was also another vehicle parked at Valet Sunday morning,  that had a completely flat tire.  Just saying with the construction across the street no one is safe from a screw in their tire.  Ours wasn't fixable,  needed to buy a new tire.The nostalgic factor makes the place more than it really is.  Something about a resident ghost and a bar and escape routes that Capone used to take advantage of makes it feel more important than it really is.  The focal point of this place is the foyer with it's sweeping staircase.  It's pretty cool.  But the rooms are small... and mine was an interior room so I just faced a wall of other rooms.Anyone who is a Hilton Honors member (ie. business travelers) should stay here when visiting Louisville.  Don't even both with the Hampton Inn a few blocks away.  The Seelbach is a historic property that's been well maintained.  Don't try to compare it to ultra-modern Hilton properties - think classic and retro, with a splash of southern charm.The rooms and suites are spacious with high ceilings and large windows on every floor.  Decor is simple - bordering on drab, especially the sofas and chairs - but the beds are comfortable and TVs are modern.  The gym is on the mezzanine level behind the small elevators and has a good selection of modern equipment, all decked out with TVs.  Bathrooms are well-stocked and not cramped.On property dining options should not be scoffed at!- Otto's Cafe does a good breakfast and better lunch, especially on Tuesday; fried chicken plate.  Prices are very reasonable and not inflated hotel fares.- The Seelbach bar is classy and historic; a great place to grab drinks with friends or co-workers away from the neon and noise of 4th Street Live.- I've never eaten in the Oakroom, however the Oakroom bar has the best selection of bourbon on site.  Knowledge local bartenders will give you a lesson on all things bourbon.Overall the Seelbach staff is excellent and I've never had an issue with any of the employees.  I recommend that you call ahead a couple of hours (well before you land at SDF) if you need a lift from the airport to the hotel.
