Shuttle departs the SDF terminal at :15 and :45 after, but during the morning and early evening it can get bogged down by traffic on I-65.  Keep that in mind.Terrible, terrible and more terrible.  For just over $ 300.00 for one night this is what I received.- Getting laughed at because I asked if there was a place to get a good bottle of Bourbon for a gift- No heat- Tiny room- No service- No late check out even though I was a presenter at conference at the hotelNever againJust a quick note. I travel pretty much every week for work and I am Diamond with Hilton. I stayed here with my wife last friday night on our way to Makers Mark distillery. We enjoyed our night there completely. The check-in experience was great; he was quick , thorough and very personable. A great combination!The room we were in was gorgeous. The hotel has done a great job of keeping the history of the original hotel but having modern conveniences. The room door had the original mail box and the closet had the glass cabinet that looked original. It was just a pleasant surprise in the era of keeping the original exterior but gutting the the interior of buildings.The location is great for staying in Louisville. You really are in the middle of downtown.I stayed here for a month and it was the best experience.The staff was excellent.The food was great.Comfort and class...The historic Seelbach Hotel is a great place to admire the elegance of historic grand hotels of yesteryear. Our room was standard Hilton fare with a nice view of the neighboring high-rises. Great breakfast buffet, albeit a little pricey.Here's some history of the Seelbach Hotel:"The Seelbach Hilton is equal parts historical landmark and architectural masterpiece. It began as the dream of two Bavarian brothers -- Otto and Louis Seelbach -- in 1869 when Louis came to Louisville to learn the hotel business. In 1903, after several years of running restaurants and gentleman's clubs, the brothers began construction of a new hotel at the corner of 4th and Walnut Street (now Muhammad Ali), creating a lavish, turn-of-the-century Beaux Arts Baroque hotel. Sparing no expense, they imported marbles from all over the world, bronzes from France, hardwoods from the West Indies and Europe, linens from Ireland, and valuable Turkish and Persian Rugs.Billed as "the only fireproof hotel in the city," the new Seelbach opened in May of 1905 by offering a 5-hour public inspection and drawing an incredible 25,000 visitors. The hotel was so popular, the Seelbach brothers began a 154-room addition in the fall of that same year.In 1907, the expansion was completed and included the famous Bavarian-style Rathskeller, decorated with rare Rookwood Pottery. Today the Rathskeller remains the only surviving ensemble of its kind.Because of its lavish elegance, The Seelbach attracted celebrities of all kinds. Al Capone played blackjack here, never far from a series of secret passageways where he could make an escape if necessary. F. Scott Fitzgerald sipped brandy and smoked cigars here, once banned from the hotel after having "one too many." The Hollywood classic, "The Hustler," starring Jackie Gleason and Paul Newman features scenes shot in the old Seelbach billiard room (now The Oakroom, the hotel's 5-diamond restaurant)."If you haven't had a chance to stay here, do so. This is Louisville's Palmer House or Waldorf-Astoria. It's beautiful inside. The history and the decor are truly amazing to see. They don't make them like this anymore.Your view varies. Some of them face out towards the city. Others face inward. If you want the sunlight to be more subdued and don't care about the view, go for the inside room. If you want a view, go for the outside.Here's a tip: Park first. If you're like me and don't need in-and-out privileges, it can be cheaper to just pay when you leave. As of now, it's $14 for 12 hours at the gate. If you put it on your room, it's $21.So why 4 stars instead of 5? Why do I recommend this if you haven't stayed here but not every time? It's a little pricier than the other options once you factor in the parking. Owing to the age, the rooms are smaller but they are well decorated. It's a great hotel but it's not completely competitive with other offers even within the Hilton family.My wife & I stayed here recently & had an "OK" experience.  The location is very close to "Fourth street live", literally two minutes walking from all the activity on offer.  The general neighborhood is dilapidated with lots of vacant storefronts & homeless people staggering around.  The hotel itself is nice & grand looking inside, if somewhat tired.  The staff were very good & friendly.  Our room was so-so.  The bathroom was tiny!  You could not fit two people in there & the wallpaper was coming away from the walls.  The room size was adequate, but it didn't have a mini fridge or bathrobes.  I thought the room service charges/cost were way too high.  A service charge + a 21% tip comes with your bill & wine is 3x what you can buy it for anywhere else.  Valet parking is $25, which I thought was too high given the quality of the neighborhood.We would not stay there again, to be honest.  If you are wanting to party the night away at Fourth street live, then this a great location as it is "staggering" distance from the bars!  I couldn't recommend it for families or a romantic getaway, based on the declining neighborhood outside.  It's better suited as a business or a special treat when you're partying & don't want to drive home location.I've listed this hotel as "pricey" based on their room rates & what the rooms actually look like when you enter them(bathroom included), as well as room service & valet costs.I stayed here the weekend of 22 April 2011. This is the first hotel which I have valeted my vehicle and I get it back with the original radio station not adjusted. This is truly a historic jewel, I agree the rooms do not have some of the amenities or features of a newer hotel but it is the best place to stay if you desire a taste of Kentucky. How many dishes can come bourbon soaked? The decor is gorgeous and this is one of the many things I love about my hometown besides Churchill Downs....Not often do I return to a place for a second time & immediately feel the need for an update... but... ... when you wander back to your room you'll notice a giant cooler of water in the hallway -- a free, open, unlocked cooler of water bottles no less. And you can have that water as a guest. Sure, I could get tap water with the plastic cups in the room. Or, I could get filtered / spring water in bottles that are cold in the hallway cooler. I've stayed in hundreds -- yeah, hundreds -- of hotels -- this is rare & this is bloody good. And worth of its own review update. The valet is still pricey *$25* but essentially essential. The Seelbach Bar is still connected *schew* and if you need to print your first draft of your prequel to On The Road in the business center on the 7th floor.. no one will notice. In all the Hilton updated hotels... the beds are always-always worth the price of admission. Free Water! (post zombie apocalypse you'll love this even more.)This hotel is beyond historic, it is a classic spot in Louisville. Beautiful walls, ceilings, winding banisters, columns. Even small, cute, old elevators (that surprisingly don't feel scary.) Going down into the basement is a must see, incredible room. As far as the rooms, they are quite nice - still that historic feel, with antique headboards. The room itself that I saw was a bit small, as was the bathroom, but the bed was comfy and there was a desk and chair and all the amenities. Not to mention a fantastic (though expensive) restaurant and classy bar to boot. At least go walk around and bask in the beauty that is the Seelbach. Tip: If you are here on the weekend, don't pay for valet! There are usually plenty of spots within a block. Meters are free Friday after 6 until Monday morning.Omg!!! Best breakfast buffet EVER!  Tamela made our day!*** HAVE TO ADD THIS***  HIT AND RUN...  LITERALLY!!We were guests of the hotel for 2 days & the rooms were quaint, the breakfast was AMAZING, but the real issue arose when we went to leave... an employee of the hotel had hit our car in the parking garage & left the scene of the accident.  When the hotel was made aware of this by the eye witness and later myself & the police, the hotel did NOTING to compensate me or make it right in anyway.  I know they cannot be responsible for everything that happens with their employees, but come on this happened in the hotel parking garage and the employee willfully avoided the situation. Not only did the hotel ignore the issue but then I had to pay for parking, I mean seriously $21 a day is pricey for self park as it is but then to have my car seriously damaged with not even so much as an apology??? What happened to customer service?  I will NOT be staying here ever again and I suggest that they focus on restaffing with responsible and HONEST employees.  I hate to draw conclusions, but if the employee who committed a hit & run was in YOUR hotel room... what would stop them from committing another crime??Thank you Mr. Eye Witness for leaving that note on my car otherwise I would have no legal recourse and would be paying for the thousands of dollars worth of repairs myself!I am leaving my rating artificially high because Tamela in Otto's Restaurant as well as Mike and Peter at the front desk made this an enjoyable visit.  The rest of the stay was average, if not below.Glorious old hotel. A real gem. Nice, homey rooms. Great service. Stately. Rathskeller room worth a 5 minute peek even if you don't stay here!Everything was great until...we left our room at 3:00 p.m. I asked the maid on the floor if she'd be cleaning our room. She said "yes." I apologized for not being able to let her clean the room earlier and gave her a $5.00 tip. We came in around 2:00 a.m. and the room had never been cleaned. The next morning I didn't want the maid to get in trouble and wasn't going to complain, but then became irritated b/c we had to hunt-down coffee and towels.  I called downstairs to the front desk (9-29-13) and informed the gentleman at the front desk that the room was never cleaned. His response was "well unfortunately a lot of the staff don't understand English. We'd be happy to refund you the tip you gave her. Sorry about that, I will let the Head of Housekeeping know." End of story. I inquired, don't they work off of a list and check off the rooms that had been cleaned? And shouldn't it have been obvious that our room was never cleaned? He said yes they have  a list, and that we should have called (at 2:00 a.m.) to have it cleaned b/c they have 24 hr. housekeeping staff.Weird and unacceptable. What is so great about Hilton Hotels? I would not stay here again.This was a comfortable and relatively spacious room for an old school hotel. In short, it is classic, old ambiance with modern touches. The Rathskeller bar in the basement is awesome. Never seen anything even remotely like it in America. It ought to be the regular hotel bar but, it's not. Overall, the place was worth the money. They had genuinely friendly and helpful staff and, if you're in that mood, being right next to 4th St. is good.I've only ever been to the bar here.  Classy establishment, even if they did let me in at one point.Great historic hotel, and more. It certainly is a grand old hotel, with a beautiful lobby, cool bar (naturally with a nice selection of local Bourbon's), and with a neat past featuring many significant people in its history. Make sure you check out the rathskeller, on the basement level. the downsides are pretty much the same for any retrofitted old hotel.. small bathrooms, lack of pervasive wireless, etc. I have stayed here many times and the staff is always great, make sure you call ahead to get your car from valet. The location is terrific if you are interested in downtown events, or 4th street live.If I could give this Hotel more than five stars I would.  It reminded me of the grandeur of the Fairmont here in San Francisco.  The rooms were comfortable and cleaned on a timely basis.  The breakfast buffet was excellent, I especially like the biscuits and gravy.  The service exemplary.We did not even hear all the noise and commotion that was going on on 4th Street.  I would definitely go back again.
review_content_60: Elegant historic hotel. So while it adds to the southern gentile charm of the lobby and Oakroom bar, it also means the rooms are old and the hallway doors paper thin. Still, it is steps away from 4th street live and it really is nice. Above average toiletries. Starbucks attached is always helpful after a night of misbehaving. Also there is a room in the basement that would be perfect for infiltrating a reception with an open bar. The name of the the room escapes me but it is very cave like and trippy.I really like staying here while in Louisville. The rooms, especially the bathroom can be small. Each room is different so it's hard to say the exact layout. The hotel has a lot of perks. They have a complimentary shuttle service that will not only take you to and from the airport but other locations around the city. The concierge lounge is nice and the staff in the lounge are nice to talk to. Also it's not a bad continental breakfast in the lounge in the mornings. The ghost tour is awesome and will take you to parts of the hotel that you may not go to otherwise. They have nice toiletries for the guests with Bath and Body Works shampoos, etc.The location is also in a good area, right off of 4th Street Live.Louisville and I are like the chemicals you combine to blow stuff up-everytime i go, I leave town with a massive headache/hangover combo. I think we need an intervention from each other.  But that's neither here nor there, so I'll get on to the hotel. Stayed here twice. It's historic and pretty, which also translates into small rooms. And super small bathrooms.  But I'm usually here for 1 night so I don't really care. The lobby is really pretty and the hotel bar makes lovely drinks. (From what I remember). They have jazz on Friday and Saturday nights in the bar. The location is perfect if you want to go to 4th Street Live-it's literally right across the street.  I've never eaten at the hotel so I can't really comment on that.I'd probably stay here again because the location is perfect.The Seelbach is a unique historic hotel that's a great place to stay on business, but probably less so for leisure. The hotel is centrally located in downtown Louisville. There are plenty of nice bars and restaurants in the immediate vicinity. The hotel also houses the Seelbach Bar which is also pretty nice.The only cons to staying here would be the age of the hotel and the small rooms. The hotel can definitely use some renovating, but its not that big of a deal for the seasoned business traveler who is only there to sleep.Checked out of the hotel today.  It's an okay hotel.  But really a Hampton Inn offers more.   don't get me wrong, it's very clean, very nicely decorated, the staff is quite responsive and helpful.But you get nickel and dimed to death.  Charge for parking $25.00/night,  wireless is 7.95/night or 45.00/week.We stayed at the Seelbach for a wedding over Labor Day. The property is located in a prime section of Downtown, a stone's throw from 4th Street Live. This was perfect, as both nights the group decided to venture over for some drinks.Rooms were really clean and decorative. Bed was very comfortable and compares to my Temperpedic mattress back home. Bathroom was small, but manageable with a large tub/shower. I was kinda thrown off by two things though: the lack of counter/sink space for toiletries and the inverted placement of the toilet/sink. In comparison to most hotel rooms, the sink was located between the shower and toilet. Thanks to my height (6'4") and the lower placement of the shower-head (about neck height, so roughly 6'), my toiletries and dob-kit would get soaked every time I would shower. I must say, the water pressure in the shower certainly made up for these minor issues.Didn't have an opportunity to experience the fitness center, but it looks very nice. Lots of cardio machines. Sunday brunch at the Oak Room was epic. We of course didn't pay, so not quite sure of the value, but damn it was tasty!The most valuable tip for anyone staying at the Seelbach with a vehicle would be to park 1 1/2 blocks away at the 5th Street Garage (630 S 5th Street) operated by PARC. The Seelbach Garage charges $16/day (without in/out privileges) or $21/day for hotel guests (with in/out privileges). Since transportation was provided for wedding guests all weekend and I knew $42 for two days was borderline robbery, I Googled nearby parking garages and found this one. The daily rate is $8.75 (without in/out privileges), but because we checked out on a Sunday (and holiday weekend), the parking garage gate was up and $42 was pocketed! If you are checking out of the Seelbach on a Sunday, I would give it a shot; worst case scenario, you save over $12/day ($21 Seelbach - $8.75 5th St). Let's just pray you don't have to retrieve your car during Tropical Storm Issac like I had to...I was just here for the 2011 Getting In Touch With Literacy conference. The hotel is beautifully breathtaking when you first enter it. The hotel staff were very accommodating considering there were many people who are blind or visually impaired staying at the hotel. The staff helped when needed and were kind. The food that was catered for the event was absolutely delicious. The rooms were small but had a lot of charm. Overall, I enjoyed my stay there.The best thing about this hotel is the staff.  So helpful.  We had an issue in our room which required immediate attention and within a few short minutes 3 people came and helped with the matter.  We were provided another room quickly and efficiently.  The hotel is stunning.  Wish we had more time to enjoy it.  One of the best fitness centers in any hotel.This was a beautiful hotel.  During my stay in Louisville (or...Indyucky...) this was a highlight.  The lobby of the hotel is beautiful--with a huge large staircase...it would be nice for a fancy affair.  The beds were heaven (though small.  they were like mini-fulls...fine for me, but maybe not for everyone)  The linens and comforters were clean and crisp and you could just fall into the pillows.The staff was sweet and nice--though they did not really give good tips on where to eat, we had to go to the Tourism Center for that...They had a nice shuttle to the airport (holla to Rick).  The hotel was quiet and clean.  There are two sets of elevators--one fast and one incredibly slow (I think that might be the haunted one...)  Crabtree and Evelyn goodies in the bathroom.The bar was dark but cozy--the wine filled to the rim.  Otto's the restaurant inside the hotel was good but the service there was so slow.  Like you should just get the buffet.  Actually when I asked for more food at the buffet (they had run out of tomatoes and mozorella...the host told me that he "thought" he could find some more...hmmm)  There is a Starbucks in the lobby (hello Lance and Will) and a little gift shop (hello advil)I had a hilarious time in Louisville--this was the best place to crash and call home for those few days.  A nice place to rest your head after your adventures.What an excellent place to lay your hear for the night! I will work my way from the outside in. Location, location, location. Situated right across the street from the night life, and walking distance from the restaurants you may want to dine at the Seelbach Hilton puts you in the mix. You can just leave you vehicle parked for the evening.One you enter the hotel, you are instantaneously aware you are in one of the finest in the city. The vibe is very classic, old world. There should have been theme music as I walked into my Fred Astaire dreamland. The chandelier was particularly impressive.The bar was perfect, enough said! Dinner in the restaurant was a good experience, breakfast was as well. Good job on keeping history going Hilton!I've stayed there many times and spend a fair amount of time in their bar, which has a good selection of bourbons and some decent live music (although I was told by one of the bartenders that the schedule has changed).  The rooms feel a bit cramped to me; it's what I like to call, the European feel.  But overall it's worth less than 100 dollars a night if you can get it, and you can...Old historic hotel, but lacks the cool vibe and amenities of modern boutique hotels. Staff is very nice, but stuffy. I guess it just isn't my vibe. What convinced me? The roach I woke up to sitting on the floor near my shoes! Gross, who wants to battle that at 5am. I will go to 21C next timeVery STRANGE hotel.  Back in 2002 came back to get my car from Valet only to be told that they had 'mistakenly given my Avis rental away.'  Then, one of the valets came out with my bottles of bourbon and CDs I brought with me and I was handed a 'hold harmless' agreement form letter.  You mean this happens all the time????  Told corporate travel when I got to airport and the hotel was placed on a 'no-go' list.What a beautiful place. Came here to eat at the Oak Room. The old world architecture of this place is wonderful.Visited April 2011.  3.5 stars ... service was nice; our room was not cleaned for some unkown reason but that wasn't a huge deal (hmmm ... or does that secure another star?).  Rooms are tiny.  We were upgraded to a suite which was nice 'cause my significant otter and I would've been trippin' over one another otherwise.Front desk staff was less than friendly but the bell hops more than made up for it. I would agree that the beds and bathrooms are small but the rooms are clean and well maintained. Even with my sporadic schedule, housekeeping cleaned each day and provided turn-down service each evening. If you are lucky enough to have access to the concierge level, you are in for a treat after 5pm and good company for breakfast. My primary complaint would be that hotel staff was rather loud in the hallways early in the morning even when I had my "do not disturb" sign hung. I was woken up several times.I wish I could have stayed here on my recent trip to Louisville. Stepping into the lobby is like stepping back in time. It made me want to dress up like an Edwardian lady, corset and all, and swish around the lobby with a parasol in hand. The interior just screams classic turn of the century luxury hotel, with lots of details wainscoting, huge ceilings, frescoes, tile, dark wood, and bronze. The hotel is a welcome change after walking through the abomination that is Fourth Street Live. I was glad to just walk into somewhere semi-civilized that returned my trust in humanity. The breakfast at Otto's was delicious, featuring a buffet with smoked salmon, creme fraiche, fruits, pastries, bagels, biscuits and gravy, french toast, eggs, omelets, and several different juices. For such a spread, the price was not too outrageously expensive. We had tried to find somewhere open downtown, but it seemed all the little cafes were closed on the weekend, so Otto's saved us.Would Stay Again.Excellent ServiceBeautiful LobbyNicely Appointed RoomsNice Lobby BarFirst Rate Dining at The Oak Room on 2nd floor.Enjoyed the history, the architecture, & the location.No complaints and room price was reasonable.I have a Love-Hate relationship with this hotel.  My company had a contract with them so this is where everyone stayed when in town for meetings.Love the Old Seelbach Bar. Lots of good times here. Beware of the bourbon-soaked cherries that the bartenders hand out to unsuspecting females!  I learned to appreciate Woodford Reserve at this bar. (I'm a wine drinker usually)I love the Big four poster Beds in the rooms. Always cozy.I love that the breakfast that is always delivered on time. Food is so-so but at least you can get a bite in and some coffee before you are ready to greet the world.I love the historic painted frescos in the lobby and the story that the hotel is haunted.I do not love that there is only a tiny shelf in the bathrooms and almost every one is tilted so that your stuff rolls right off!I do not love that the doors have a good 1 1/2" crack under them so that you can see people's feet as they walk by in the hallway (and enjoy their conversation). Not to mention the blinding light shining on you as you try to sleep.Last but not least, I do not love that the rooms are all so very dark even with all the lights on and that the elevators work sporadically.PS. Never had any problems with on-time shuttles but never trust the wake up call system!Very friendly staff, great hotel overall with lots of things to do and places to eat within walking distance. The front desk was able to upgrade me to a queen junior suite due to my diamond status with hhonors. My only gripe is that parking is a hassle as I generally prefer not to use valet.
review_content_80: Legend has it that this hotel inspired the setting of The Great Gatsby.  It's worth a stay for the history and architecture alone.  The Oak Room used to serve much better food.The Old Seelbach Bar is still a great place to hang out and pretend to be a movie star.nice to stay somewhere that was not Generic America.Great hotel with great service.  My room had a four poster bed and was very nicely finished.The only downside with an old hotel is the size of the rooms, if you tried to swing the proverbial cat, you would bang it's head on at least two walls!The hotel bar is awesome, listed in some magazine somewhere as one of the 50 coolest bars in the world.  I dont know that I would go that far, but it was quaint.I will stay again if in LouisvilleCrappy overly priced hotel... good central location but better to stay at the Marriott or other hotels in the area.  It might be historic, but the room doesn't need to feel like it.  The food was horrible... thankfully a Starbucks is caddy corner to the place.Overall, crappy. Don't waste your money.Thankfully it was a decent hotel considering it was teh only one with a room left before the Derby.  There is a Starbuck's off the lobby for your morning jolt.A historic hotel, indeed. The Seelbach had a part in The Great Gatsby (called the Muhlbach Hotel in the novel, F. Scott Fitzgerald was stationed here prior to WWI) and was also a haven for Al Capone in the whiskey-running era. These days it's a well-maintained, small, stunning establishment.It was ok. Lots of history and character. We do occasionally bring out of town guests here to peer in on the al Capone room and the rathskeller. We stat a couple of years ago--just not my taste. Room was very small. Bed was very high. And the abundant ghost stories made it a bit spooky (especially in light of the decor).  3 1/2 stars--giving an extra 1/2 star bc of the oak room and rathskeller.

review_content: Girlfriend found this place on Yelp. Yes I turned her into a Yelper and it is working out well for me. Super friendly staff! A woman spilled coffee in her car they gave her wet rags and even went out to help clean the woman's car. Food was delicious and the drinks are great. I would certainly stop by for lunch again.I don't understand the hype with this place. I had the lamb and grits, and it was SO SALTY. Seriously, the only flavor I could taste was salt (and a hint of mint). I couldn't finish it and had to drink two glasses of water to balance out the saltiness of the meal. My partner ordered the speculoos crepe, and he enjoyed it quite a bit. No complaints there.How delightful is this adorable home with a bed and breakfast above it?You walk into a quaint room with an open kitchen and dining room. Well, not quite a dining room but tables and a "bar". They offer local brews and fantastic options for vegetarians and meat lovers. My dad went with the bahn mi tofu and I went with the duck biscuit and gravy? Why not? It was my freaking birthday!I feel as if we waited less than five minutes for our lunch. Seriously. It came out as soon as we both ran to the restroom and came back!The food was delicious and our beer paired nicely. The man at the register is to thank for that!There are a few other items I am intent on trying... Including the bahn mi. Pops adored it. See you soon, Gralehaus!We have been dying to try this place since my boyfriend moved to Louisville. The kombucha on tap is what sold us. We finally made it, and I wish we would have tried it long ago! The decor is awesome- the place is so fun inside with the decorations and the furniture. It has tons of different beers and signs around and it just looks great. We studied the menu for a while... There were multiple options we both were looking at and could decide. I ended up going with the veggie hash and he ended up getting the lamb and grits. And of course, a kombucha. The veggie hash was SO GOOD. it was better than expected-- it had potatoes and broccoli and Brussels sprouts with awesome sauces and an egg on top. I wish I could buy a jar of the sauce and put it on everything. The lamb and grits was also awesome. We devoured everything in less than 10 minutes. The kombucha was top notch-- a little pricey for 5 bucks a pop, but it was good.We will definitely be back for breakfast again and hopefully to try holy grale as well too! The food was pretty quick and service was good overall.The charm of the Holy Grale and its Biergarten continue in the Gralehaus, a must-visit spot for brunch. It also offers a unique bed and breakfast in the Louisville Highlands -- I'll just have to have my next out of town guests stay here so that I can check it out!  Situated in an old Victorian house, the atmosphere is just as one would expect from a Holy Grale- affiliated establishment -- warm, inviting, and come-as-you-are casual. The staff is friendly and enthusiastic, with excellent recommendations on the menu.  I visited recently with a group of friends for brunch, and we were immediately struck by how comfortable and charming the place was.  We sat in the corner by a window, and were quickly greeted by a staff member. Orders were to be made at the counter, they told us, and we quickly filed up to place them. I went with a decaf coffee (pour-over, but worth the wait for it to be prepared), and a vegetable hash. The food was brought out as it was prepared, and we each ate our meals while they were piping hot. I dug into the hash and loved its hearty mixture of root vegetables with a sunny-side-up egg over it all. Hot, savory, and filling, it was just what I needed for a brunch meant to tide me over until dinnertime.  After a filling meal in great company, we vowed to return again. A new favorite place may have just been found!Mocha is best, doesn't burn your throat with sugar, soft and nice. Hot chocolate and other coffees are very nice too. Chess pie is too sweet for me but is good. the cups are really nice and the place has pretty details.Holy crepe! This place is delicious!After some confusion about the location, which is directly behind the Holy Grale, I arrived in front of the quaint house that the Gralehaus occupies. The sign out front clearly indicates this place is for brunch, but also for snacks! They offer a soft serve ice cream that looks yummy, but I did not order. My mind was on a savory crepe.While waiting in the line to order, I decide on the country ham and cheddar crepe. The crepe itself was a beautiful soft, fluffy texture. It was shaped almost like a pie crust around the contents of salty country ham, cheddar and runny egg. On top were some greens for additional texture. It was absolutely delicious and they didn't skimp on the meat!To drink I had fresh hand-squeezed orange juice. It was $5, which I thought was a little high priced. However, I am not a coffee drinker, so this was one of my few options. If you are into the java I would highly suggest a latte or espresso because they have a very, very expensive piece of equipment to make those. It looked like a Modbar.If you are into the booze for brunch. They have that handled too. Grocery refrigerators line the back, full of beer options. There's even a beermosa!My friend ordered the french toast. The size was unexpected. It was one very thick slice of white bread topped with some sort of pumpkin butter and whipped cream. Also, very yummy but I wasn't blown away by it like I was with the crepe.Keep in mind this is a small restaurant. A few tables and then some bar style seating on a wall and another section right next to the expresso machine. In cooler months make sure you have jacket/coat as you may be eating outside if it's super busy.I thoroughly enjoyed my meal at Gralehause, the ambiance and the people watching (people flow in and out with drinks, food, soft serve). It's a do not miss in L'Ville.Great little spot. You would miss it if there was no sidewalk sign. Great interesting menu, nice comfortable interior and the Porchetta sandwich was great. The brunch menu looks great and it would also be a great spot to meet friends after work.I have been there twice for Sunday brunch the staff is rude. I will not be returning. This is very disappointing as it is in walking distance and is in a great locationInteresting place, you order at the counter then find a place to sit. I ordered the bacon egg biscuit and it was delicious! Staff was friendly and Accommodating. Will definitely come back for brunch.This place is pretty tucked away! If it weren't for yelp I wouldn't have known it were a place for the great bites. I tried it for brunch! Yummy! Try the the duck biscuits and gravy! It was a great take on biscuits and gravy without being anything you've tried before! It's also a great place for coffee! They have all kinds of brews to try. If coffee isn't your thing try the beer! Wow! Lots of great choices!Just one more note . This place is pretty tiny so don't bring a party of twenty! ;)If "brunch" means four trips to the all-you-can-eat fried chicken bar to you, this might not be your joint. A dude can very quickly go broke just coming in here for a biscuit and coffee.Rest assured, you're not just paying for the surrounding reclaimed wood or the cook's beard trim.You're paying for the ridiculous glory that is their speculoos crepe. You're getting local ingredients and "haus"-made sodas and soft-serve flavors and garnishes. Craftsy kombuchas. Capriole cheese. Wee tins of fancy homemade things invented for Instagram. Great beers, great patio, and great attention to detail.It's taken me more than a year to admit this, but you win, Gralehaus. Here's my paycheck. I'm yours.Gralehaus was smaller than I expected, but don't let that fool you, it's still deserves an A+. The tonic/soda drinks were great and very refreshing. The crepes were AMAZING! I had the country ham one and my sister had the speculoos one, so I was able to have both sweet and savory. I highly recommend the speculoos one. The breakfast sandwiches are delicious. My other sister had bacon egg and cheese on a biscuit, and it was divine. The biscuit was so soft and fluffy--perfection! I also ordered a beet salad but I recommended you skip out that as it seemed to be half a cup of canned beets :/Other than that, everything was great! Also, the outdoor area is beautiful and I recommend sitting out there on nice days!After driving in to Louisville late the night before, we wanted to kick off derby weekend with a solid breakfast. We checked out Holy Grale the last time we were in town, and apparently the same owners opened up a breakfast spot right next door. From the outside it just looked like a regular house. In fact, I accidentally went up the stairs while looking for the bathroom and the rooms upstairs looked like furnished bedrooms. I think I heard that they are expanding to become a bed and breakfast sometime in the future. The atmosphere kind of reminded me of one of the hipster brunch places from some of the neighborhoods around Chicago. The vibe was definitely casual and laid back, with wooden decor and unfinished brick walls. While the breakfast menu was small, all of the items seemed to be original and unique. They didn't just serve up the usual pancakes/eggs/bacon dishes that you can just get at any diner. In addition to breakfast, it looked like they also specialized in coffee and craft brews, since they had fridges full of different beers and the bar seemed to have a type of taps for espresso. We stuck to breakfast food, but the lunch menu also looked great (too bad it wasn't 11 yet).  You order at the bar and just find a seat yourself.Affogato - Their version was served with soft serve instead of regular ice cream. It had a stronger coffee flavor and didn't really combine together to create the richness I wanted.Biscuit and duck gravy - Excellent dish. The biscuit was fluffy and airy, and wasn't mouth-drying like how biscuits can sometimes be. The gravy was super thick and rich and had huge chunks of meat in it. The egg on top was cooked perfectly and the overall presentation just looked really nice as well. I also really liked the drizzle of syrup around the edges to give it that bit of sweetness among the heavy and savory items in the dish. Crispy pork hash - This isn't really what I was expecting. I was picturing something more like corned beef hash that had a crispy edge from the grill. Instead it was almost like a deconstructed hash with huge chunks of roasted potato and a little bit of pork. There was also broccoli and a smear of salsa verde on the plate. I think the meat ratio was off and could've used more pork in the dish. Overall, Gralehaus seemed like a cool place to enjoy some beer or coffee and grab some original, re-invented breakfast dishes while you're at it.I absolutely LOVE this place...the Tofu Banh Mi is the best I have ever had.  It's a perfect lunch with a kale salad and a date to share.  They give you plenty of tofu, and it's thick, savory and delicious.  The people who work here are very friendly ----environment is visually wonderful! Great space.I couldn't rave more about the brunch I had there many times. It's by far on of the best in the area. The Duck Biscuit and Gravy is amazing. I've probably had it more than any 1 human has. I'm also a coffee lover and they serve cortados here and they too, are outstanding. Give this place a try and you'll keep coming back.It's a super cute, tiny brunch spot! It got that hipster-ish, country chic feel to it. I came here for brunch one Saturday morning with friends and would definitely come back for more happy meals with small groups. It's another great spot to show off Louisville, or to just love and enjoy Louisville. It's perfect for mornings when you feel slightly hungover (or ahem tired) and not wanting too much fuss (water being refilled, server asking if you want anything, etc...) over your meals. Just you, your favorite people and good food.Space: It's small and cozy. That means you might have to squeeze a little if you have bigger groups, or just don't expect to sit at tables that will fit 8 or 10 peeps. There are about 2-3 tables that could fit bigger parties (of 4), some seats around the bar and a few smaller tables. We were able to squeeze around a small table. It was tight, but the good food made up for it.Bellies: The "super fat" drink was "super good." My rich, sweet drink came in a mason jar (cute) and tasted like a delicious combo of caffeine and soda (I forgot if it was rootbeer or coke). This is not relevant, but the chef in the kitchen that day had curly chef-style mustache, which screamed to me "great food!" I had lamb sausage and grits, which was delicious. I'm not a sausage fan, but occasionally will try and if I like it, that means it's really good. I loved it! It tasted lighter than usual sausage and not at all gamey. I finished most of it (minus what I shared) and wasn't as eager to share as I usually am. The trout salad looked pretty, but wasn't as popular at our table. I'm guessing the fish was cured or smoke and tasted fishier than we would've liked. It was probably an acquired taste, like the shrub. The prices are a bit higher than your average self-served cafe, but the quality of the food is also above average.Service: You order your food at the counter and things are brought out to you. You're on your own for the rest, so there really isn't much to complain about, since no service was expected. The guys were friendly at the counter and patient when we asked about the drink. None of us knew what a "shrub" was.Summary: yes, I will definitely come back.Went last night for dinner with a friend of mine. The restaurant is really cute, but I didn't get the vibe that this place required you to go up to the bar to order at first. So after about 10 minutes of going over the menu and waiting, we decided to go up to the register to order. Figuring out that you go up to order was the only thing odd about this place. I ordered the lamb and grits, my friend ordered the Friday special (fried cod, roasted cauliflower and hash brown casserole) and we split some potato salad. The food was delicious! My grits were creamy and cooked all the way, her fish looked flaky and didn't reek, and all the sides were awesome!! The drink menu was fun too! She got a beer mimosa and I got some kombucha tea. I also like how you can refill your own water from the giant mason jar thing!I definitely want to go again sometime. Since it was cold yesterday, it wasn't really busy... But I can see this place being popular in the summer!I love how many fresh, items there are on the menu here. We went in for brunch and we're not disappointed. My hubby ordered the bacon, egg and cheese sandwich on a pretzel croissant. They ended up forgetting the cheese but it was still tasty. I ordered the country ham and pimento cheese tartine. It was the perfect blend of salty, sweet (with the bread and butter pickles) and savory.  I only had 2 real issues. One, there wasn't really a good side option for either sandwich and the sides were a la cart, which makes breakfast for 2 about $35-$40, including drinks. The other problem is I really like coffee. I like brewed coffee, but they only have pour over. It's not the same. It's weak. Other than that, I really enjoyed everything. The back patio is beautiful and has fresh herbs growing in the back. Overall, this is a great place to try.Amazingly good food and a boatload of craft bottled beer. A treat! Shares a courtyard with Holy Grail.
review_content_20: Our favorite breakfast and coffee in Louisville! The patio is great, when weather permits. French toast and any coffee drink has been delicious and consistent.Delicious food, great atmosphere, and really good coffee and espresso. The staff are super friendly. It's all about the details!Yet another fabulous meal! The Pork Hash was a great surprise typical of this place. The crispy pork was complimented perfectly by the verde sauce which changes based on whats fresh locally. Roasted broccoli and redskin potatoes hidden under a perfect sunny side up egg was an awesome combination. So many places burn the egg and ruin the dish. Thanks for the perfect yolk to burst and mix with the other flavors!  I love the house made hot sauce!Went there on a Saturday morning and was pleasantly surprised by how fast we got our food. Cappuccino and biscuits and duck gravy were amazing. Girlfriend loved the tea. Service was awesome and prompt. Relaxing atmosphere. Small but in a good way. Will definitely go back soon.It's an easy place to miss if you aren't looking for it, Gralehaus is located in a normal residential looking home. The ambiance and food is not so normal. The menu is small for breakfast and consist of crepes, southern dishes and an assortment of tea/soda and coffee that I'm excited to explore. Plus there is a selection of beer on draft AND bottles/cases for purchase.The Food: lamb and grits. The grits was so creamy and delicious I could eat another bowl of it alone. I've never had grits without shrimp and the lamb patty it came with matched well in flavor.  Plus the dish left me feeling very satisfied despite walking in starving.Corned beef and hash: it hit the spot! Especially the brussel sprouts it came with. The potatoes were rather large pieces but flavor still got in. It's definitely an adult hash.Pretzel croissant (without butter): okay croissant with salt is a hit or miss in my mind. This time Gralehaus definitely succeeded in hitting. The salt is present but not overwhelming. Plus the pretzel without a slathering of butter actually helped balance the flavor better.The restaurant seems small at first with some four tops inside and a bar. A bar that allows you to watch the food being made. This is the definition of an open kitchen! I was so distracted watching Andy cook. There is a nice back outdoor seating area that's 21+. If I had a small celebration or party I'd love to use that space!This place has quickly grown to one of my favorite, "I'm in need of an ice cream" places to go.  On a very embarrassing number of occasions I have come to this place simply in need of a cortado and a huge bowl of soft serve and brownie.  Really, there is more to this place than that, but I can't stop getting that every time I go.  The flavors of the soft serve ice cream rotate and so far I've had lavendar, blueberry, and a few others I can't even remember.  But I ALWAYS get the brownie and it is superb.A few other favorites:Cortado (or any espresso drink, they use Intelligentsia coffee/espresso) and it is yummyA specialty beer infused with espresso (this rotates too, just choose whatever they have!)PRETZEL CROISSANT.  salty goodness right there.  Also, come for their Sunner nights on Wednesday and Thursdays for some 'never ending' $2 7oz pour kolsch beers on the patio.  It is crowded and on a hot night, that kolsch really hits the spot.Came here for breakfast while going through Louisville on a road trip with really no idea what to expect. First impression from the outside and inside was that it was a hip little spot, reminded us of Portland. You order at the bar area and the two ladies behind the counter were super friendly and helpful. The menu is pretty simple but everything sounded good, especially the wide variety of specialty coffee drinks. I ordered a beermosa (a cider and orange juice), I have to say it was the perfect morning cocktail. My girlfriend got the crispy pork hash and I had the biscuit and duck gravy, both had really good and unique flavor to them and although the portions looked small they were actually perfect and filling. Would definitely come back again, especially since they told us they're working on adding a bed and breakfast upstairs.Gralehaus is a transcendent experience. A holy trinity of coffeehouse, restaurant, and Biergarten. Und gothic masterpiece. Split fantastic biscuits and gravy, and a lamb sausage and grits, alongside a hot pretzel croissant. Everything was so good, we wanted to double down for seconds. A fantastic place to come for brunch, dinner, anything. The only criticism was the quality of the cortado I had; but it was still incredible. I can't wait to come back to louisville and visit again.Coffee is out of this world good!  Crepe was beautiful but a bit too salty. Nice place.I couldn't have loved Gralehaus more. From the moment we walked in, I knew I was going to love it. The smell of coffee and bacon smacks you in the face when you open the door of this little house - turned - brunch and beer haus. This little gem is warm and welcoming, with simple but well thought out design, and friendly and happy employees. The worst part about my visit was deciding what in the world to order! The menu is chalked full of tasty breakfast and lunch options, coffee/espresso drinks, and interesting cocktails. I went with the breakfast sandwich made with country ham and a biscuit, accompanied with a maple iced coffee. Completely divine. My friend had a BLT with a side of the best grits I've ever had. (Creamy, flavorful) she also had a watermelon mint soda. I can't wait to revisit this cozy little place and try something new! Louisville is kicking butt.We were hungry tourists trying to find some good cookin' in Louisville and found this gem. The food was amazing, the staff was so friendly, and the environment was pretty chill. The place has cool exposed brick and authentic wooden floors. You order your food at the front and get to pick your own table. They had a really cool self-serve water pitcher at the front with mason jars. Overall the food was really good. I got a Country Ham and Egg Crepe and it was delicious. I would definitely recommend that and a beermosa (beer and orange juice).If you're looking for a great brunch in Louisville, then look no further! 3 days at the Forecastle Festival means 3 days of brunch, and for my money this is the place to be. Take your seat in a small, almost crowded (but not quite) seating area, pick one of a handful of delicious, interesting options that add welcome twists to traditional brunch fare. Don't miss one of their "Beermosas" either, made with fresh blood orange juice or ginger, and a Belgian Blonde Ale. Bigger isn't always better - Graelhaus churns out top notch food in a small little kitchen in a cramped little brunch bar. Avoid the crowds and get the good stuff!After reading previous reviews, my sweetie and I selected items based on recommendations ... Duck gravy biscuit for me and the Speculoos crepe for her.  Both were fantastic! Research later revealed what Speculoos actually is and found a recipe we will likely attempt at home. Had no knowledge about this delectable Belgian spice cookie but the crepe was a winner. You might come up a little short on coffee (quantity) because they wonderfully drip-roast each cup individually.Still cranking out wonderful foodCrispy duck biscuit and gravy totally rocks everything great on your pallet and fills your tummy with plain ole goodness my rating still there five YUMS!I love breakfast food and this does not disappoint. Ended up getting the bacon egg and cheese biscuit and the bacon was to die for. The biscuit was perfection. Will maybe branch out to a speculoos crepe next time! I will be back!I don't think the woman who has taken my order during my two visits likes me very well. She doesn't seem too happy to see me and her manner is what I would call "officious." She corrects my pronunciation (porc-hetta not porch-etta) but not with a caring tone of voice as if she were speaking to someone new, but rather with the tone of voice that indicates a person who's already been told a thing, but has failed to understand. That's not the case so let it be, I figured. And, I confess, I find the menu here not only baffling, but my order time has been a bit rushed here on both occasions given how challenging the menu is. Meanwhile, folks lined up behind me (exposing every lack of knowledge I might have). Today, I asked about beverages (having tried the ginger ale on my prior visit) and settled on something called a coffee cherry soda. It was explained to me that "coffee cherry" is a part of the bean. I like coffee--so I ordered it. Along with a corned beef sandwich (I'm not eating a thing I've been corrected over!) and a side of potato salad. Once I sat down with it, I realized it has a vinegar flavor that was, for me, unbearable (they called it "shrub" whatever that means). Two sips and I was working on a bit of heartburn. So, I walked back over to the counter and asked to try the coffee soda instead (I had seen the woman in line after me receive hers and it looked OK). The server acted a bit miffed with me but said all the right things. I offered to pay but she insisted I just take it in substitute. I wondered if she thought maybe I'm addicted to sweet flavorings as every sip I've had at Gralehaus has been, erm, bitter in flavor. So, I tipped an extra couple bucks and went about my business. The coffee soda was a bit more to my liking, but still a bitter concoction, at least I recognized the flavor of coffee. Soon, as I gazed at the chefs doing their thing, all was forgotten.  The rye bread used for my corned beef sandwich was real dense and dark just the way I prefer it. The potato salad was interesting, if not spectacular. As my meal progressed, I caught the chef whistling along to Black Sabbath and a few of us at the counter got a mild chuckle out of what must have been a first ever in the known Sabbath world. I am not yet shaken by the consequences of my ignorance (and perhaps a modicum of server attitude). Third time will be the make or break experience for me and Gralehaus.The food is surprisingly good. It's a tiny place and it fills up fast. We fortunately were there for breakfast just a little after nine on a Saturday morning and had no trouble finding a place, but by the time we were leaving, it was standing room only. We ordered an egg and cheese on biscuit and the famed duck gravy and biscuit. I don't understand how they can take a fatty cut like duck and make it so non-fatty. Hats off to the chef. The egg on both plates were cooked just right and the light greens dusted on top, combined with the gravy to create a perfectly balanced combination. The coffee is drip and consequently slow. Not very good either, but that wasn't terribly important compared with the food. You order at the counter and they bring out your food when it's ready. There is a bar which adds more seating and it's done nicely. The place is cozy with reclaimed wood and a wall fridge with a zillion kinds of canned beer. They have some on draft as well. You serve yourself cold water that is positioned at a window overlooking a bunch of overflowing trash containers--just not pleasant. A single cup of hot tea runs $5 so the bill adds up quick. Tea, coffee and two portioned breakfast entrees rang it at a little over $26. Don't expect anything like a Diet Coke or Equal--how inappropriate you heathen! Overall it's good, but a little too trendy for me to have it as a go-to place.Another win for the owners of Holy Grale and the Louisville Beer Store!I finally got to enjoy brunch at this tiny spot, and I'm really looking forward to going back ASAP.I started with the maple latte, which provided a sweet start to my meal. And that continued into my brunch entree, the speculoos crepe.Never heard of speculoos? Well get ready to have your mind blown! This is a devilish concoction that is also known as cookie butter. It's as if peanut butter and biscotti cookies had a baby ... that you want to eat as quickly as possibleSo at Gralehaus, you can get this in a crepe. Perfection.I also tried the cheese grits, which definitely stand on their own.Gralehaus has a selection of single beers available to purchase, and I'm hoping to try one of their breakfast beer cocktails soon.The restaurant is super chic on the inside. Like with the owner' other spots, style was definitely top of mind. I particularly love their choice of light fixtures, use of chalkboards at the main counter and subway tile around the kitchen.Gralehaus packs a big punch in a small space and is worth a trip.oh there's something about this place that will keep me coming back. Not sure if it was the decor, food, or the atmosphere. Actually, it was all of them. When arriving, it was rainy and I was waiting on a good friend (emily h.!) for brunch. It was quiet. A few people enjoying their fancy coffees, mimosas and intricate crepes. Right then, I knew this was the perfect day to be here. I grabbed a table by the window and saw the barista working her magic behind the counter. I wasn't in a hurry but noticed that no one was waiting on me. After several minutes, she came over, handed me a menu and said to order at the counter whenever I'm ready. Then it hit me (duh!) this is just like holy grale where you order at the counter and they bring you your food. ah ha! Makes sense ...I ordered the organic blend 333 tea. It was a nice compliment to the ricotta toast. Light and not overwhelming. The ricotta toast should be named something more elegant like "heaven on toast" or something. When it came to the table, the presentation was fancy, but it looked like i would be starving afterwards (only 2 pieces of toast and some ricotta. whoohoo.) it did have a good amount of pistachios and greens. Plus, everything together was the perfect marriage ... the flavor was soooo lovely and delicate. I ate it slowly because i wanted to enjoy every bite, and since I ate it at a turtle pace, I was full afterwards :) win, win! I'm excited to take my husband next time. He'd love the beer case and the overall feel of gralehaus. The best way to describe this place:   Gralehaus = brunch.I started with the maple latte, which was a great choice, it was sweet and fun.  I ordered the lamb grits and my wife ordered the duck gravy and biscuits.  The lamb grits I didn't like much, it's probably because I don't like grits but I wanted to try something new. The lamb was amazing I'm just not a fan of grits so if you are, it'll be very good.  Now the duck gravy and biscuits was absolutely mouth watering, it's they twist on the sausage gravy and biscuits.  The flavors were very fresh and the duck surprisingly taste almost like a bacon.  We will be back to have more brunch
review_content_40: Came here for New Year's Day Brunch. Had the best cheese grits EVER!. Also had the Crispy Pork Hash, this had potatoes, broccoli, pork and a fried egg. It was full of flavor. My wife had the Ham & Egg biscuit.Will be trying the crepes on our next vist. Inside was neat also. Brick walls hard wood floors.I love this place, but I really don't go that often.  For breakfast... I'm normally elsewhere, typically Toast on Market and for lunch/dinner, I'd almost rather go to Holy Grale(same owners) if I'm in that vicinity.  Going in the middle of the day... I usually end up with a breakfast item & a lunch item.  I'm not sure I'd be satisfied with one or the other.  I can't really knock it because the food has always been great.  I'm not really a fan of the ordering.  It's not that it's bad.  You order at the register and they bring the food to you.  That concept isn't a bad one because I don't have an issue ordering in that manner at other places like Holy Grale or Grind.  Something about the way this particular spot is set up throws off my balance.I'm not really knocking a star off for any of that.  I am going to knock a star off for the tipping here.  I don't mind leaving a tip.  I normally tip anywhere in the 20-25% range, even if the service is mediocre.  Here you pay at the register which is an iPad and it asks if you want to tip.  Of course it's not a problem to just not tip and wait on your food, but that question shouldn't be put in front of the customer until after service has been given. Food is great.  Atmosphere is great.  Layout is okay.  Ordering & paying could be worked on.  I really wish you could order, eat, then pay(& tip if you choose).Great, artisan breakfast/brunch items. A little pricey, but very good. Duck biscuits and gravy was amazing. Unique breakfast drinks, stout ran through coffee beans, beermosa, and flavored belinerweisse. Great beer selection in the fridge. Multiple rare lambic a as well!Food was fantastic.  The biscuit with duck gravy was good, but the ginger crepe was one of the most unique dishes I've had in a very long time.The coffee was a pour over and a little bitter.  This also means you don't get refills.As far as service it was neutral.  Not friendly, but not rude.  You're going to come here for the food not the warm southern welcome.I made it very clear I am pregnant and the egg must be thoroughly cooked. However, they served running egg in my crepe, I did not notice that until I am half way through the crepe. The egg in the second one is still running, they refunded me but still, an unpleasant experience.I think I am not cool enough for this place. I have been here a couple of times for brunch and have been absolutely mesmerized by the food. The duck biscuits and gravy, the crepes, the cheddar grits - I mean, heavenly.But, why is the waitstaff always acting like they would rather be anywhere else but here? They sort of skulk around silently, don't smile, have a rather "meh, so you are here" attitude. Our waitress brought coffee once, and just set the mugs down. When I asked her for some sugar, she reacted like she had just been snapped out of a trance - like asking for sugar was the most incredulous request I could have made outside of "Could I be spoon-fed my grits while reclining on a down filled cushion and being cooled off with 2 handsome men waving palm fronds at me". Look, your coffee is great, I will give you that - its just that some people like cream and/or sugar with it!It makes for a somewhat uncomfortable dining experience, and on an early Sunday morning, I just want to relax and enjoy myself - not worry that I am doing something uncool that will have people sighing and rolling their eyes. Maybe I have just hit this place on two bad days - the people leaving five star reviews seem to say that I have - and I really hope so too. I have to order those crepes again!$13 for a burger seems a bit steep. When you realize that is for just a burger only, it seems even steeper. When it takes over 30 minutes to receive that burger and the two employees working that day are rude and defensive, it seems outrageous. For that price, you may as well go across the street to Jack Fry's, get an actual server and the service that justifies a +$10 burger.Gralehaus may be one of my new favorite weekend breakfast/brunch spots. I came here on a quiet Saturday morning and there was no wait. It was actually fairly quiet, but it was also 10:15. You order at the front and then they give you a number and they bring out your food. It was nice enough to sit outside so we enjoyed the porch seating. I had the Egg, Ham, and cheese sandwich on a biscuit. It was wonderful! Portion sizes are comfortable too! I also tried the beer cheese as my friend ordered it. The beer cheese here is the cold cheese, but I'm a fan of that so no problem with me. The actual pretzel itself was probably one of the best I've had in Louisville. I tried one of their APAs on tap and would definitely order again. I think it was called Bruxton. All in all a great laid back morning. I'll be returning soon!Awesome cheese grit, hash and gravy. Plus, they share the same outdoor patio with Holy Grale, so it is a great place for brunchThe people who started Louisville Beer Store and Holy Grale don't do anything just halfway. So of course their third venture in town is amazing. Incredible sandwiches ... I love the porchetta, but the turkey is also great -- and a very cool atmosphere. They recently started serving dinner and the one time I tried it, it was great. Have also heard excellent things about their coffee -- I'm not a coffee person but my wife is, and they use Intelligentsia from Chicago -- and the soft serve. And you can buy hard to find craft beer from the cooler (or have a beer float). Love it.Okay so you can say I'm addicted. Mimosa's for $7 and the winter squash crepe and lamb and grits...what more could one want to start the day. The eggs are always cooked perfectly and the atmosphere is super.This is the most unique coffee shop I've ever been to. Walking up the concrete steps, it looks like you're about to enter someone's home. Hard to believe a business is actually there...Once inside, the place clearly is an industrial coffee shop with exposed brick, metal, and wood. I fell in love with it at once. It's got more character and feel than 99% of every other coffee shop. Don't be boring and opt for a normal latte-- try the maple latte, a beer and espresso shot combination, or a slew of other unique mashups that you won't find anywhere else. Whoever came up with this concept is a creative Einstein. I travel the world in search of hip and cool coffee spots, and Gralehaus now takes the top spot honors. If you love coffee and an un-Starbucks-like experience, this is your place. Go, go now. You'll thank me later.Decided to come this restaurant with my friend after church since another place we checked out had a long wait. I was definitely not disappointed that we missed out on the first place! This restaurant is a tiny place but the atmosphere is extremely nice. The old wood and highlands feel is exactly what I wanted on a sunny Sunday for brunch. We both decided to get two different plates since we were hungry. I got the Speculoos Crepe and the country ham and egg biscuit, both which were presented so nicely and tasted just as great. I'll definitely come back and check out this place. The prices are a little higher than some brunch restaurants but since it's all local and everything is so fresh I think it's well worth spending that extra money. See ya soon Gralehaus!I arrived in Louisville in the early afternoon on a weekday and decided it was time for second breakfast. Gralehaus definitely delivered.After several days in Kentucky, and not yet having biscuits with any meal, I chose the biscuits with duck sausage gravy, with maple syrup, duck cracklins, and sunnyside-up egg. This was hands-down one of the best things I've eaten in a while. I also had a side of the white bean caesar, which was okay, but paled in comparison to the biscuit. I want more. Now.It looked like seating was very limited and I feel lucky I visited when it was relatively empty. The staff varied in their warmth; some were friendly, others stone-faced. Interesting, considering the lowest auto-grat available on the square app at checkout is 20%, and it isn't even full table service. (Maybe this is somehow tied to the coffee, and the ability to tip $1 on a coffee drink, I dunno.)All the dishes me and my friends had for brunch were amazing! The place is cute,  looks like a house but inside is very cozy.  Definitely recommend for brunch.  Cappuccino is also very good.My wife and I visited Gralehaus on a Sunday morning for brunch. There was no wait to order from the disinterested employee behind the bar. We ordered our food and coffee and went out back to the beautiful outdoor seating area. The coffee was delivered and was exceptional. The food took about 25 minutes, but that was fine.  We had coffee and an excellent morning with nice surroundings. When the food arrived it was very good.  So, the coffee, food and atmosphere are great so why not more than 3 stars?  The people. Unfortunately the staff act as if they are doing you a real favor simply by allowing you in the door. The employee taking orders could not have cared less whether we ordered food and coffee or if we left. Coffee was delivered to the table by another frantic hipster who said nothing before running away.  In fairness, the third employee who brought our food was very nice and helpful when a problem came up in the order. Gralehouse employee number 4 was less than interested in fixing the problem, and was quite annoyed that I wanted the food I had ordered. So it's really up to you, the food and coffee are very good. If you don't care that the people seem too cool to be bothered with you, it's worth a trip. I prefer when I spend 30$ on breakfast, to not feel like a burden on top of it.It's a super cute little place with a great patio for days when it's nice outside. The lamb and grits is so delicious!  The lamb is perfectly seasoned and pairs well with grits and eggs over easy.  They also have a great selection of beers.  We are always going back time and time again.Appreciating this coffee bar more and more after getting over the shock of the Euro-pretense, which I don't get. Isn't really very reminiscent of any German or other European establishments I know of . . . beside the point, I really like the alternative choice here to the dumpy, dark, average seems okay, coffee houses in Louisville. AT least here we get to read the menu on the wall, where it belongs. And you don't have to bring your reading glasses or a flashlight to guess what is available here for pastry or, yes, lunch items!!! Imagine that in the third wave of Louisville . . . you can eat here! BUT.... I can do without the $5 latte, $4 Cortado and $3 Mexican Coke pricing, and maybe that's all this place has to do with any euro-place - pricing. Coke in a bottle is not cold (more euro sensibilities), espresso is not extracted well, Intelligentsia I have had hundreds of times elsewhere, and here I don't even recognize the Black Cat - something is up, perhaps too fine a grind to start with - that's my two cents. "Barista sez" extraction is automatic and below the fancy steel machine. I vote for more by-hand control, perhaps a normal LaMarzzoca would do nicely. And then steal the barista culture from the other shops to run it! I'm running out of reasons to go here . . . besides the cozy feel in a Highlands house.??!Excellent lunch in a comfortable setting. Nice people with a great bottle beer selection and just a few really good taps. Strongly recommend for small groups or single people. Not a good place to bring a crowd. Try the picnic plate to get a good selection of most everything. Pimento cheese was the best I've ever had.Dude, the maple latte is awesome. Atmosphere is great and the food is great. We had brunch and it was fairly quick. Again off Bardstown road so parking isn't great. A win for holy grale.
review_content_60: The country ham and egg crepe was amazing! You have to sit at the bar overlooking the kitchen!We went here while we were waiting for space to open up at the Holy Grale. It was the 2nd night they had been open for dinner. Their menu is brief - 3 breakfast options and then an array of pub food. They don't have liquor but several refrigerators full of microbrews wine and non-alcoholic beverages.It is small inside! I was with 5 more people and there wasn't a table that could accommodate us so we just took over the bar and high-top table area which was pretty decent for socializing just not a fancy atomosphere.I had the chili dog which was just okay. The hot dog was meaty. The chili was very middle of the road. The pretzel bun it came in was somewhat stale and didn't have any salt on it. My colleagues got the burger and raved about it. I also had the beer cheese and pretzel. Though the cheese was decent, it would have been more enjoyable warm so if you go here, ask them to warm it up for you!I'm giving this place 5 stars because it was very convenient. Their menu is exploratory (alabama fried rabbit, what?), their beer selection is awesome. It was affordable and the employees were easy going and enjoyable. I'd definitely go again though I'd probably get something else.Oh! I forgot about the grits! The grist were awesome. Sharp cheddar cheese on them. I ate them all. I've tried grits many different places during my Louisville travels and I enjoyed these the best.Blown away! Coming from the Seattle coffee scene, I never expected to find Intelligentsia coffee, kombucha on tap, knowledgeable baristas, unbelievable micro brew selection, clean, simple, delicious food, all in a little tucked away cafe in a historical district of Louisville. The food was made with love, and the shredded ham on the breakfast sandwiches, and in the crepe was salty and flavorful. The server who took my order over the phone was very friendly and sweet. He also put our pour overs in an empty beer carrier. Really brought it home!!!Need a good little breakfast spot? I've found it for ya. This quaint restaurant was perfect for this morning's breakfast catchup with a friend of mine. I ordered a bacon, egg, and cheese sandwich (I opted for the biscuit instead of the pretzel croissant, which I probably should have chosen), and it was scrumptious. Maybe my favorite hidden treasure of Gralehaus was that they carry Sprecher sodas. If you are a cherry cola person (I am! I am!), Sprecher cherry cola is the best out there. I'm not a coffee person, but my friend is. He loved his cup o' joe. The environment was much like a coffee shop, but it's in the back of Holy Grale, which is an old church converted into a bar/restaurant/cafe/coolest place there is. It was a cool way to start my morning, and I look forward to going back in the future. I felt much more hip just by having been there; and I'm probably the most un-cool person on the planet. Thanks, Gralehaus, for starting my day off with some good food and great vibes.Super friendly and so ridiculously tasty. I had the country ham crepe and cheesy grits. I had to buy a bag of the intelligentsia gralehause blend coffee. Seating was kinda sparse (I sat at the bar) so I wouldn't come here with a big group. I can not wait to come back again during my visit , probably tomorrow!Whenever I have an out-of-town friend visiting, I take them to The Gralehaus. While the menu isn't kind on the calories, if you're looking for a hearty meal which is heavy on the classy, comfort food spectrum, this is the place for you. They do a wonderful job with their German-American Gastro Pub fusion. I've had both the Biscuit and Duck Gravy and the Lamb Sausage and Grits - both times, it was a lot to get through, even though the portions weren't massive (compared to American standards), but worth the distended stomach. Every moment was like being in a gravy-smothered heaven.On the beverage end of things, they're just as impressive. They're the first coffeehouse in Louisville to serve Intelligensia Coffee, and while I have a bit of a heartache on the non-local choice, Intelligensia is a treat. Gralehaus has perfected their Sorgum Latte, which they serve with a Biscoff cookie. It's a strangely savory drink, but don't let that deter you from ordering it. They use local, full-fat milk in all their espresso drinks, and so the Sorgum Latte is what blues standards on vinyl and a pile of knitted blankets taste like.Finally, the shrub sodas. I had the Rhubarb and Tarragon, and I'm going to warn you now: they don't sweeten them. But you don't want them to. Because this tart, vinegar-y drink is strangely delightful. Fresh, crisp, and more refreshing than any carbonated beverage I've had the joy of experiencing.This review is getting to long, so I'll make this part short - the inside is stunning. I want my house to look their restaurant. Intimate, wooden, rustic, hand-crafted. Very pub-like.I just need to start writing love letters to this place.They put the Stir in the Hip"stir"!Brunch in Louisville is a tough crowd. Tough because we love it so, so much that the first brunch after their official opening I found myself heading to gralehaus. To start I was lucky. Lucky, because there is very limited seating inside this eatery but I got one of the four tables. The other eating spot is a long wall table with stools, but the place probably seats around 25. Lucky, also because even for their second day open there was a crowd. A crowd of all the coolest 20 somethings in town. We say and probably watched them serve 50 people in an hour. So be prepared to place your order to go or wait for a table.Table service is at a minimum, we got menus, but then stood in line to place our orders. gralehaus gives you a number or takes your name for your order. We had to get up and grab our drinks and dress our coffees with creamer and sugar at a side table. However we had a server who brought out our meals. The meals came out as they completed so there was a small bit of staggering until everyone was eating.Our group tried the fresh OJ, your basic Americana coffee, and a Sorghum Lattee. Apparently, the coffee is made from beans that require you to have your pinky up while brewing. Understandably while drinking our beverages we could taste all the love within the amazing flavors. My latte was a memorable personal experience. For our meals we ordered the duck crepe, the ham crepe, and the grits and sausage. The food was light but filling. The flavor of the dishes were balanced, savory, and well executed. I believe my entire group was impressed by how perfect our first visit to gralehaus was considering it was only their second brunch!When I return I will be reordering my Sorghum Latte with the ever so spicy sausage and grits. The gralehaus experience allows me to hit pause on my personal life and check in to a quality thoughtful personal experience without being as uncomfortable and inflexible as yoga!There's not a single thing on the menu that I don't like. The atmosphere is great, I love all of the outdoor seating, and the affogato - DANG Y'ALL.This is my Saturday morning/brunch spot nearly every weekend (I only miss the weekends I'm out of town...)Louisville To Do's blog post on Gralehaus : goo.gl/GVkeKnHighlights: Best crepes I've had in the States. Incredible espresso drinks. Intelligentsia Coffee. For about $20-25 two people can have a lovely morning. My girlfriend and I love this place. If you're going for breakfast I recommend going between 8-930am, especially on weekends, since the sleeping-in crowds and the church crowds start to get heavy after about 1030 or 11am. Haven't tried their sandwiches yet but they look delicious. The interior decor is simple, minimalist, yet very cozy and charming. It's a treat on the eyes as much as it is on the palette. Now to address complaints: First off, this city doesn't appreciate what it has with places like Gralehaus. Common complaints I've heard are lack of seating and how busy it gets during peak hours. Yes, Gralehaus is small. So don't be a jerk and camp out all damn day like Louisvillians tend to do. Trendy brunch spots in Portland, Oregon, for example, will urge patrons to sit with strangers if they have empty seats, and don't linger any longer than you must. People in this city are friendly enough, and often pretty open to a nice stranger joining them. Same etiquette applies for the Gralegarten when the picnic tables fill up. As far as complaining about a place being busy during peak hours, just take a second to think about how obvious that is. If you're in a rush and don't like crowds then maybe rethink where you go for food. You might have to wait a bit and be flexible, but it's worth it to chill out and adapt. For good crepes I also recommend Java on Bardstown Rd. and the crepes stand at the Beargrass Creek Farmers' Market on Saturdays off Browns Blvd in St. MattsThe fall squash crepe rocked. The cortado punched through the morning fog. The kitchen watching was fun. Do folks really spend 16 bucks for a bottle of beer?Kombucha on tap? A for effort but I'm not a fan of the current pineapple flavor. The seating is quirky as noted previously. Dining counters should be wiped away from cooking surfaces, not toward them. Did I mention the fall squash crepe rocked?I have never had anything here I didn't absolutely love. Crepes are amazing! They are a must try. Get a beer bloody mary or mimosa to top it off.Went for breakfast. Unique menu. Everything was delicious! Get there early, it gets busy and there isn't much seating.Went to Gralehaus for breakfast with the girlfriend. The decor was very nice and does carry the feel of its neighbor Holy Grale. The reclaimed wood ceiling was pretty cool to see.Everything on the menu looked enticing. We settled with ordering the lamb sausage grits and biscuit with duck gravy. For drinks we got one of the teas and a sorghum latte.Girlfriend had the lamb sausage and grits dish. The tastes I had of The lamb sausage were absolutely delightful and reminded me of the lamb merengue from 4505 meats in San Francisco who itself is a delightful meat purveyor.
