Grits were the right side of creamy, and mixing it all with the seasoning dusted on top with a runny egg just oh so good.The biscuit with duck gravy itself is something I would recommend I others that are looking for a tasty hearty breakfast item. The biscuit was tasty but might put others off looking for the usual buttery flakey type of biscuit. The pepper biscuit was of a somewhat cakier texture, but does well with the duck gravy. The gravy had substantial heft in flavor and thickness, and the drizzle of maple syrup provided that a pleasant sweetness. The sorghum latte was good too and not overly sweetened. It just had the right mix of ingredients for a creamy, slightly smokey sorghum finish o a typical latte.Thank goodness I am far away enough from Gralehaus so I am not tempted to make it a weekly breakfast stop otherwise I might go broke visiting so often. I am reserving giving a five star rating till I visit a couple more times to get a feel for more of the menu items, but do think Gralehaus will be able to obtain it.I enjoy crepes and they deliver some tasty crepe options. I also enjoy imbibing during breakfast, of which they have very tasty alcoholic and non alc options. Huge fan of the tonic treat, and pimento cheese, and anything they offer pretzeled.Note: This review is only for Gralehaus as a coffee house Derby City Joe Review #11What makes this Coffee Shop Sing? - There are a ton of reasons to visit the unique Gralehaus. However, if your primary goal is discovering a great coffee shop, you might want to head elsewhere. Tucked away on Baxter Avenue, Gralehaus' presence is marked only by a couple of tables outside and a small sign. If you need a landmark, try looking directly next door to the world's only KFC 11 adding to that strange, wonderful dichotomy that is the Highlands. The cafe joins a somewhat crowded landscape of places to grab coffee within a mile of one other on Bardstown Road. But Gralehaus is certainly different and not just because they don't open until 8:00 AM (take that as a note of caution, bleary-eyed early risers).In fact, it's a bit of stretch to label Gralehaus as a coffee shop. It might be more apt to describe them as a loveable mishmash of a dozen other entities - cafe, bar, breakfast nook, beer store and even a dessert shop. They ONLY offer pour over style coffee as opposed to conventional drip coffees. And it's not the kind of space where you feel invited to sit for an extended time. However, there aren't too many places where you can purchase coffee and pickled eggs and beer mustard. Not that such a need usually arises, but, hey, one can never be too prepared. It feels a bit like you've stepped into someone's old home when you first enter because...well, you did. When the proprietors, who also own the beloved beer tavern Holy Grale, gutted the house late last year, they did a fantastic job. It would have taken Bob Villa and Norm Abrams at the helm to produce better results. There are also plans afoot to convert the upstairs into a small bed and breakfast by late fall. All that being said, Gralehaus doesn't make for a particularly good coffee joint. The rest of the menu features a relatively limited selection of coffee beverages, but enough to satisfy most basic orders. There were virtually no other patrons besides me since I'm guessing most of the activity is later in the day. Beyond coffee, there are extensive, eclectic menu items such as soda teas, duck gravy and a variety of unique beers on tap. The back door takes you to an adjoining patio that directly connects to the Holy Grale.As I said, it is probably not fair to judge this one as a coffee house. Gralehaus is a cool place to visit but lacking as a standalone coffee joint. Coffee of the day: The two pour over options available that day were custom blends from Sunergos and Intelligentsia. I tried the Sungeros and found it watered down and weak. I often find that pour overs typically have more flavor, but my brew tasted a bit like a cake that didn't quite rise. Hard to discern any specific flavors. I was a bit disappointed.Cost of a small mug of Joe - $3.18 (The higher costs due to the pour over method being the only option)Cost of a Refill - Also $3.18Staff: Given the full range of the menu, both my server and the cook were affable while busy prepping for the day. Crowd: The morning I visited, there was virtually none. Decor: Fairly limited seating and certainly one of the smaller spaces around. However, Gralehaus makes impressive use of every inch of space resulting in a comfy and cozy environment. One nifty touch is the old bags of coffee beans that have been repurposed as artisanal window shades.Wi-Fi: Locked with password.Music: I was treated to tunes by Iggy Pop, Real Estate, Roxy Music, Wave, Max Demarco, The Clash, and Foxygen. My ears approve. Bonus: The coolers on the back wall are full of endless six-packs of truly unique, craft beer available to grab and go.Gralehaus was a joke. The staff were in over their heads and couldn't recover. If you risk it here tip AFTER your service is complete. After clicking the lowest suggested 20% tip at the counter ordering service I got robbed since I got my own water, my own silverware, my own drinks and had to prompt my own food from the servers. We sat for 20 minutes next to two soft mannered gentlemen astonished at the haphazard service. We brushed it off but with no sign of our coffee my girl went inside to inquire. What she received was an angry bartender assuring us that he delivered our drinks but to the wrong table as if this was to clear him and satisfy us. Finally he apologized for his rudeness to my lady and she brought back our drinks. Then our food seemingly came outside and circle the patio only to go back in. When it came out a second time I gained the clueless server's attention. If you don't know who's food it is why not call it out instead of wandering like a lost, hungover puppy? The grits were good, the breakfast sandwich full of butter and tasty. Nowadays a sleek metal and wood lined eatery with good beers are a dime a dozen. If the servers are going to make me do all the work and yell at my girl forget it. I'm out.Hit up Gralehaus for brunch the last time I was in Louisville and absolutely loved it. It's a well-cared-for house across the street from the church and makes for an amazing setting. The patio is clean and well-groomed, and the lines of gutter-pot gardening on the back shed looks great.The food is awesome. I had the biscuit & duck gravy, which was easily the best thing I'd had all weekend.The service is a bit ad hoc; my friend didn't get his food for some time after I did (as well as a party that had arrived about five minutes after us) until someone wandered out and noticed him still waiting.I'll definitely visit again the next time I'm in that part of Louisville.This place is GREAT! Yummy, hipster, intimate, and fun. I came here with my beau for a bite of mindfully made food & cool options. We ate our food too fast to take pictures, let alone talk between bites. The soda didn't stand out as particularly interesting flavor-wise, but it was a great alternative. We can't wait to go back!Delicious in every way. A fantastic atmosphere. But my husband needs a lot of food to get full. The portions are great for me but too small for him- especially for the price. Special occasions place for our budget!Absolutely perfect atmosphere. The small space somehow manages to feel incredibly open and the dining area is surrounded by low-set windows that breathe in just the right amount of light on this rather overcast day. The food was delicious and well-executed. Plating was pleasing without being over-the-top or pretentious. Overall, the food was the least surprising element of this excursion - coming from same team that brought us the Holy Grale, you just EXPECT delicious food. One critique: more vegetarian options are needed. My only disappointment came from the last place I expected - the coffee. While you can tell the Intelligentsia Coffee is superbly roasted, the beverage itself was weak and watery. I'm sure they'll have everything in this department perfected in short order, given the fact that there are some familiar baristas here that seem to have migrated from Please & Thank You. With that being said, my latte was spot-on.
review_content_80: We wanted to check out a new brunch place in Louisville and this popped up so we gave it a shot. The place is very small so but the turnover is pretty quick. I had the duck biscuits and gravy with a maple mocha beverage. The duck was seasoned and cooked very well and the gravy was just the right amount of sweet and savory. Overall I thought that the meal was delicious. My counterpart had the pork hash but it had too much garlic on it for her to enjoy it. I am a fan a garlic and have to say that it was even too much for me. We also ordered a side of hashbrown casserole which to us was just par for the course. Overall we had a good experience but for the price I think there are better options in the area.So glad I discover Gralehaus! The food quality is suburb and the pour over coffee is the best I've ever had. I'm a bit of a snob when it comes to coffee and I could not wait for the next cup of coffee at Gralehaus. Yes, I bought the coffee ground too so I can have it every morning. Both breakfast and lunch items are delicious. I highly recommend the lamp sausage and grits as well as smoke pork hash. They are well prepared, very flavorful and most of all, you'll come back for more! So glad this place exists.I had the duck sausage biscuits and gravy and cheese grits. Both were pretty good. Service was efficient but very unfriendly . Decor was beautiful . Beer selection and overall menu is pretty diverse . Good place to stop for lunch or casual dinner.Went in today to enjoy a nice lunch with my dude. Ordered the Porchetta with a side of grits. He ordered the BLT. The holy trinity of lunches to say the least. The Porchetta definitely stole all the limelight. Probably one of the best sandwiches I've had in Louisville so far, and, man, I really love me a good sandwich.Tried Gralehaus out for a Saturday brunch with a friend and we LOVED IT! The atmosphere is so cute and quaint and the food is amazing! We had a breakfast sandwich on the haus biscuit and the crepe with the gingerbread cookie thing in it. Both were delicious! Definitely a new favorite weekend spot!For the aesthetic alone, this place is worthy of its exceptional reviews. Inconspicuously located behind the infamous Holy Grale, this little cafe reminds me of a more bohemian French bistro. The food is incredible. I've been six times for breakfast and the dishes are savory and cooked to order. Spicy Lamb sausage with cheese grits, duck gravy biscuit with honey and an egg that's always cooked perfectly. I still can't fathom the depth of flavor in these items. It's insane!They are one of a handful of American coffee shops with a Mod Bar system. It would be more impressive if the Intelligentsia they serve tasted more like their coffee from Millennium Park. It's simply harsh, and not balanced like shots they'll pull at Sunergos or Quills. Cappuccinos come out really hot, and shots taste over extracted and bitter. I would write this off as a fluke, but I've had five now and it's the same every time with different baristas. I love they serve Intelli, just wish it was Black Cat and as epic as it's supposed to be. If you're not into coffee, it's ok - as their fresh squeezed orange juice is superb. Try it in a mimosa! Beer selection is diverse and plentiful. So many great Belgiums and IPAs. I would rather them slightly markup the beer, dislike paying an extra $1 for a glass - but I'm sure it has something to do with their license or profits. Overall, I would recommend this place to anyone coming into Louisville seeking insanely high quality brunch and good coffee. I have no idea about the bed and breakfast upstairs, but the downstairs has me hooked. Go right now, and put everything in your mouth!When I heard that the owner's of my beloved Holy Grale were opening a bed and breakfast/deli/cafe/lunch spot, my salivary glands began working overtime in anticipation. Close to a year later, they're open and gralehaus is as good as it gets. The prices are reasonable, the food is flavorful and the atmosphere is cozy and inviting. Despite our better judgement, my boyfriend and I arrived at 12:30...on a Sunday...on Valentines weekend. However, we were pleasantly surprised to discover that, despite our poor timing and gralehaus's limited seating, we only waited about ten minutes for a table to open up. In that ten minutes, we ordered the Sorghum latte and pour-over coffee. The pour over was awesome and the sorghum complemented the espresso beautifully. It wasn't too sweet or syrupy tasting. For our meals we ordered the the Lamb Sausage and Grits $7 and the Biscuit and Duck Gravy $6. Both were to die for! they both were full of flavor without being too rich. We didn't get around to try their beer cocktails but i'm sure they are equally as impressive as the food and coffee.The atmosphere and menu is unique but the breakfast we ordered was just not spectacular enough to justify the price. The artisan coffees are a nice touch, but also on the pricy side. I also don't like that the iPad app that you pay with asks for a tip before you even get your food.Great little cafe. Came here while traveling on business, and was not disappointed. The food was amazing and the coffee was full. Had the Haus Bologna and a cappuccino. My friends ordered the chorizo crepes and the biscuits and duck gravy. Everyone had good things to say about all of it.Phenomenal. Great ambience. Incredible mind blowing perfect coffee. Delicious food. Perfect location. I really hope it stays a little secret because they are in a teeny tiny space - but they have used it really well.Definitely not going there again.  $8 for a plain BLT with no sides and $8 for French Toast that was skimpy with virtually no flavor and a really odd crunchy texture.  After adding on a single coffee and tax, the bill was $23 and we were still hungry.  For that price, you walk out of most restaurants fully satisfied.  The place was crowded and noisy right after we sat down.  Might be a good coffee house but the food and coffee is really overpriced.  We'll be heading out somewhere else for our Sunday brunch.I hate that I even have to give them one star. The service was horrible, and the prices were insane. The food was good even though over priced. I don't recommend this coffee house.Sensory perfection. Thoroughly enjoyed: the indoor aesthetic, outdoor patio/garden, cappuccino, pour-over, courtesy & expertise of staff, lamb sausage, grits, and breakfast sandwich including homemade biscuit, fresh parsley, & just the right amount of seasoning. Wish I could have tried everything on the menu; beer cocktails, kombucha on tap, and sodas sounded especially interesting. Can't wait for the haus part of the vision... Hope next time I'm in Louisville this place has launched their B&BGreat food and service without all of the pretense. Get in my belly! :Pbrunch, beer for here, beer to go.FYI: It is small: two four tops and the rest is bar seating. 8am - 8pm EVERY day!Yum!I loved Gralehaus and would definitely recommend. I had biscuits with duck gravy, lamb sausage w/ grits and trout hash. All three of these are served with a fried egg on top. Can't go wrong with any if these entrees!I want gralehaus to be successful. I really do, but part of me wants it to stay a little less known so I can go there for a quick breakfast or drink whenever I want.I visited gralehaus just a few days after it opened with my breakfast loving boyfriend and a good friend of mine. Immediately upon entering, my boyfriend stated that he felt like he wasn't in Louisville any more. gralehaus does have a unique atmosphere somewhere between a tiny coffee shop and a Waffle House. It's clean, cozy, and beautiful inside with an aesthetic that I would liken to a fresh take on a wood-filled lodge. Once we took in our surroundings, we noticed that there wasn't really a place for the three of us to sit. Seating in the small restaurant consisted of two bars that seated four each, two or three high tops that sat two each, and two picnic tables that looked like they could fit six each. Unfortunately, the tables were occupied by groups of two, and at the bars sat single diners who chose to sit in the middle of the grouping of seats, preventing us from sitting together. We awkwardly stood by a high top trying to figure out what to do when a group of two sitting at the bar offered their seats to us and moved to a high top instead. We placed our coats on the hooks under the bar facing into the kitchen area and went up to the bar to order.When I asked about vegan fare, they replied with "not yet," a response which left me hopeful for the future of the restaurant. There are only a few options for vegetarians, but some of the dishes with meat can be modified to be vegetarian. I ordered a haus mimosa, biscuit and sorghum jam, fennel and ricotta toast, and a side of grits. My friend ordered a coffee, side of grits, and ham and cheese crepe (without the ham.) My boyfriend ordered the biscuit and duck gravy and coffee. Our order ended up being around $60. We were handed a number and sat down.I'm actually happy that we didn't get a table, because the bar we sat at was the best seat in the house. Directly in front of us, the chef expertly prepared dish after dish, executing every crepe effortlessly. Our food was handed to us, and we dug in.My boyfriend is extremely picky about coffee. I wouldn't say I'm as picky as he is, but I do think I have a pretty good handle on what is "good" coffee. He was so excited to come to gralehaus strictly because of the type of coffee that they served and the training their baristas received. This coffee was wonderful. Even as we progressed through a single cup, the flavor evolved. Truly wonderful. My mimosa was not a traditional mimosa, which I knew going in. Featuring beer and grapefruit juice instead of champagne and orange juice, it was more of a shandy than a mimosa, but it was good. I don't think that grapefruit juice is quite as effective a pairing with beer as orange, but it wasn't bad.My fennel, ricotta, and grapefruit toast was good, but I didn't feel it was worth the price that I paid for it. Next time, I will definitely get the ham and cheese crepe, without the ham of course. I can't imagine how good it must be with the meat included because even without, that was one of the most delicious breakfast items I've ever had. I was expecting strictly egg and cheese flavor, but it was so light and flavorful that I wish I could have eaten more. My boyfriend also loved his entree. I liked the biscuit and sorghum jam, but I felt the jam was too rich for the portion I was given. The grits were cheesy and wonderful, though my friend thought they were a touch too salty.After we finished our meal, we wanted to sit and chat for a while, so I ordered my friend and myself a kombucha on draft and a peanut butter and jelly con panna for my boyfriend. Those kombuchas were so light and refreshing that I truly think that I'll be coming back just for them sometimes. Vastly superior to store-bought kombucha and for just a little more, I highly recommend them. The PBJ con panna was also excellent, but was so rich that we couldn't finish it.I hope to return soon to try some of the other items on the menu, especially the soft serve and sodas, but I think I'll try and hit it at an odd hour when it won't be so hard to find seating. I definitely recommend gralehaus, even though it may mean my new beloved breakfast spot becomes a little more crowded.Only disappointment- the $2 chips are a pre-bagged product. Otherwise a great food experience.We tried to go to the Holy Grale but they were super busy so we walked out back to the quiet sanctuary that is the Gralehaus. Delish! I loved my Burgoo - which was essentially yummy pork shoulder & sausage soup with white bean and chickpeas. I'm going to try to make it at home and wrote down the ingredients. My friends ordered the croissant sandwich, crispy pork hash and squash crepe. All were delicious!Five stars for the food, three stars for their pricing and policies.  Just had lunch and it is definitely one of the best burgers in town.  All of the ingredients were good quality and most of the toppings appeared to be made in-house.  One issue I had was the price.  $13 for a hamburger for lunch.  I understand using top ingredients costs money but $13?  For lunch?  With no sides, no chips, no potato salad?  Then my other pet peeve.  Many of these type restaurants are doing this these days but they have the checkout where they ring you up, swing the monitor around and ask you for tip and signature.  The options were 20%, 25% and 30%, or custom tip.  First thing I am of the school of thought that you shouldn't even have to tip when you're ordering at the counter and all they do is ring you up and drop your food off without asking if you need anything, etc.  How can they expect a 25% tip, the same as a full-service restaurant. I would also say how do you tip before the service is rendered, but they're not really rendering any service.  I suppose he pushed the right buttons on the register. Anyway they're not the only place who does this.  I would love to go back because the burger was so good, but I probably won't because the checkout process irritates me.  Can you tell?

review_content: Such an excellent hotel!!!!! Everyone from the bell boys to the front desk to room service and housekeeping was superb and extremely friendly. They're extremely accommodating and affordable. The food is great and they have a free shuttle to and from the airport which is very convenient and it's less than 10 minutes to the airport.Room was very nice and clean and thermostat is very responsive which was a godsend as it was blizzarding when I stayed.I told you that I'd be back! This time I brought my daughter. She loved it and said that she'd rate it a 5 (she's as picky as I am).Again, I scored this hotel on Hotwire, as a 4.5 star listed hotel. The only reason that I I'm not going to rate it as a five star, is because the first room that I got over a year ago, was smaller and less impressive as this last time. This time... room 531. It was a corner room, that over looked the corner of W. Broadway and Forth Street. This room was a lot more spacious and the noise level of outside feedback was non existent, completely different than the last time. In a nut shell, I agree that it's a 4.5 star hotel. Another alteration since my 2014 stay/review... now there are several other hotels, closer to Forth Street Live. The brewery that was across the street was demolished.  Did I mention that they have free wifi? The valet parking is now up to $24 per day, but after spending $70 per day in Chicago, that rate didn't seem so bad.The Brown is charming and has a lot of very lovely old features. I was honestly going back and forth between three and four stars. Not because I had any bad experiences but because The Brown needs a little sprucing up. I ultimately decided with four stars because everything else was really truly wonderful. The building is very very neat. Built in the 1920's it retains much of it's original "parts" for lack of me knowing the exact term. Original molding on the walls and ceilings, lighting, furniture, doors and windows etc. This makes the hotel so cool, it is truly beautiful. We were able to just walk around the whole place, some of the ballrooms were open and we peaked in. Really really beautiful and from a bygone era. Our room was small and quaint. Very clean and the bathroom was a nice size. The bed (king size) was very comfortable and there were plenty of pillows. I called ahead and asked about getting a room with a good view. They gave me a view of downtown and while I could see some of the city it was not a stunning view. Maybe that is just the location of the hotel, I don't know anything about the area so I don't know. It was still a lovely room. The bar is definitely a place you will want to check out. It's just as beautiful as the rest of the hotel and a very nice place to sit and have a drink. They have lots of bourbon!!! Our bartender was fantastic too. There are a lot of small tables to sit and order food in the bar area and it filled up quite quickly on the Saturday evening we were there. The service at The Brown is definitely a high point. From the moment you pull up to the valet you are treated like a VIP. The front desk staff was excellent, very friendly and accommodating. Overall takeaway is this place is beautiful and a very nice place to stay. The only down side is it does need some freshening up, new paint and carpet (no bad carpet smell though so don't worry about that). Just a few updates could really let The Brown shine. I don't know if I would for sure stay here next time only because there is another hotel I want to check out in Louisville but if there was a great offer I probably couldn't turn it down. I absolutely recommend a stay at the historic Brown Hotel!Great, beautiful hotel. Free hot apple cider and delish hot chocolate at check-in, BUT nooooooooo coffee in the morning! Really? Come on now. :|The small bowl of the "Soup of the Day" or "The Potage" as they call it, in the bar was waaay overpriced at $9. I would guess the shallow bowl help maybe 4-5 ounces, at best, and didn't taste good at all. It was cold. It was mushroom. It will not be ordered again.Gotta love it when you get to stay in a little slice of history!  And that is just what The Brown Hotel is.  With it's nod to the grandeur of an era gone by, this hotel is understated elegance at it's finest that hasn't been seen since the 1920's.The rooms are large and the beds super comfortable. And the bathrooms are large and well stocked with toiletries.   And if anything seems wrong, it's the flat screen TV that is hanging on the wall.  I kept having flashbacks to another time . .what was that movie . . .oh yes . . "Somewhere in Time" and that's what this reminded me of.The lobby is up on the 2nd floor and it is stunning with the soaring ceilings, the gilded cage area and the sweeping staircase up to that level.  Stop in the bar, have a drink and then sit and linger awhile.  And if you have time- swing into the restaurant and have a Hot Brown.  This open faced turkey sandwich is huge, smothered with cheese and bubbling hot.  And they serve it all day!If you drive, the entrance is around the corner from the main street.  Valet will take your car on that side or you can park in the parking structure.Love this town!  And The Brown just adds a little more class to the entire place!This is a grand old hotel that has been beautifully restored and shows a lot of elegance from old ago.  The hotel is also the home of the original HOT BROWN -- a classic Louisville sandwich tradition.  I've have "hot browns" elsewhere in Louisville but you owe it to yourself to try one at the home of the original hot brown.  We were there on a Sunday afternoon and ate in the hotel restaurant which is really quite elegant -- not your typical casual or quick causal dining place but a fancy sit-down restaurant with white table clothes and the works.The hotel itself is a nicely restored older (1920's era hotel on the fringes of downtown.  It's not right downtown but is close.  As an older hotel, the rooms are on the small size but are nicely detailed and quite comfortable.If you're looking for a big generic room - this isn't your kind of hotel.  If, however, you're looking for the elegance and grandeur of a long gone era -- this is the place for you.  It's a classic and they just don't build them like this anymore.It's almost unnerving how personal the service is at check in.  From the stunning old world architecture to the classic antique furniture in every nook of the place, to the incredible servers in the lobby and the chocolate on your pillows and the spacious, modern bathrooms...this place rocks.  The chef is an award winning, serious professional.  Every dinner I had here involved him coming personally to my table and offering various samplings of seasonal experimental offerings.  The dessert was to die for.This hotel is very grand and lobby is beautiful. Our room was a king size standard. It was still very spacious and the style felt really classic, it was not extremely modern like some other hotels. They preserved the original vibes of the historic hotel. What I was really excited for was the famous Hot Brown and boy...I was not disappointed. I was staying in one night and wanted to try it and room service had it delivered within 20 minutes. It was the best thing I've ever had. It was turkey cheesy goodness. Overall, this was a must see historical site in the city and loved my stay there. Very professional staff and clean. Also very accommodating.Not impressed. 4 star hotel? That's silly I stayed here because of a week long seminar that was booked thru the seminar. Checking it out online gave me a relief to see that it was a 4-star hotel. But staying here for more than 1 night, I beg to differ. Now I don't want to take away from the staff, they are incredibly friendly and willing to help. Very professional. So I appreciate that part of my stay. But the hotel it self is bunk. Really old and to be a 4-star hotel u would think they would at least have water in your rooms. Nope. No water. In fact you have to go to the vending machine if you want water. And hope your vending machine takes dollars, by my 3rd attempt I just ended up getting 10$ in quarters because the damn machines wouldn't take my money. Lol. Silly. The rooms are very out dated. But they do keep nice sheets and towels. Cool. Wifi is fast. We did get a visit from the security, which was a load of poo. We literally just got off the elevator and the dude was talking about how he was getting complaints about noise. ???.........fucker it wasn't us. ! O well. All in all the stay was pleasant. Just wasn't impressed at all on the claim that it was a 4-star hotel. If you want to stay at a 4-star, go a couple blocks and stay at the 21 C hotel/museum. Now that my friends is a real 4-star. From service, to rooms (that have water) , to the whole experience. ............I've stayed two times at The Brown, and have been blown away each time by the impeccable service of each employee I had the pleasure of speaking to. The first time we stayed was on our wedding night. Upon booking our room my husband mentioned that it was our wedding night and they upgraded us to a suite (for free!) and although we didn't get to spend as much time as we would have liked at the hotel the sentiment is still the same. We loved the room, the service, and the history of Louisville felt while staying here. The room was extremely clean. The beds are comfortable. And check-in/check-out was a breeze.Upon our second visit to The Brown we were looking for a low-key anniversary celebration and decided to stay here. They asked if we were celebrating anything when we booked the room and my husband explained that we were staying for our anniversary. They upgraded us to the "club level" which gave us access to the club lounge. From 5p-7p each night they have a spread of appetizers, and each morning they have a breakfast spread and Starbucks coffee available. Everything was delicious, and the service was very friendly. If you're looking for a modern place to stay... READ: The Brown is not for you. The Brown is not hip, modern, and new, but that's all part of its charm. The Brown doesn't aim to be hip and modern, it aims to preserve the history of this Louisville landmark and present it in the way it was when The Brown opened in 1923. If you're prepared to enjoy this iconic hotel in the way it was meant to be enjoyed then you will love your stay!I was told that while in Louisville that I needed to try a Hot Brown and that the best place would be where it was created, the Brown Hotel.  I came here for dinner and got a little confused on where to go as far as a restaurant is concerned so I ended up in the Lobby Bar. The name says it all.. its a bar in the lobby of the hotel on the 2nd floor.  It was open seating so I found a little two top and was promptly greeted by the waitress.  The selection of bourbon is as you would expect here but I opted to stick with water as I a more of a beer person and had my fill the previous night (they do have a decent beer selection).  When my Hot Brown came out it was really hot, as to be expected.  At first I was bummed that it didn't look like what I saw on Man vs Food but then again, does it ever look that good?  The flavors were pretty spot on.  The bacon was really tasty and the turkey was not overly dry (a tad but nothing like mom over cooking the turkey at thanksgiving).  The sauce was to die for and I only wished that they would have added more than they did.  The dish was filling but the price point seemed a tad high given the type of dish it is but definitely worth doing if you haven't had it before.The ambiance is nice but very loud. It may have been the people but I believe that since the piano playing in the back ground was so loud it forced everyone to yell at their table mates to have a conversation.  The service was excellent and the architecture is pretty amazing.  Even if you don't stay here, come for dinner or lunch.I did make a stop inside the gift shop on the first floor as I was leaving.  They had some really nice items to buy as souvenirs so I picked up a few packs of bourbon balls a gift back of bourbon smoked spices. Giving this place 3 stars was a tad rough, but after thinking about it and having experienced it once I may not go back unless I bring my wife.  Not that it was a bad experience because it wasn't, but because there are a lot of restaurants to eat at in Louisville.A group of friends & I decided to travel to Louisville for New Years Eve. A friend was able to get 3 rooms on Priceline for around $100 a piece, including taxes & fees. To my understanding, the normal prices for these rooms are a lot higher. I think $100 bucks a room is a steal in downtown Louisville. We arrived around 6pm on New Years Eve. They are currently doing some type of construction on the street that has a the garage entrance & its a little hard to find. Once inside the garage we noticed that overnight parking is a step 20 dollars. I don't know why, but paying for parking when you stay at a place REALLY annoys me. If the room was $120 & the parking was free, it wouldn't bother me. Something about having to pay for parking when you pay for a room just annoys me. Anyway, off my soap box. We parked on the 4th floor. We had to take the elevator in the parking garage to the 2nd floor to get to the skybridge that connects the hotel with the parking garage. The door to get into the hotel had a key card lock on it, meaning you had to have a key card for the hotel to get in. We were lucky enough to be entering with a person who had a keycard. We checked in to get our key, a little hiccup because the front desk clerk gave us a key for a room that another person in our group had already checked in. We went down to the front desk and we were able to sort it out. Our room was on the 5th floor, we had two queen beds & a bathroom. The view was of a roof of the building. I didn't expect much for being on the 5th floor, & we weren't planning on looking out the window all day. The bathroom was quite large for a regular hotel bathroom, a lot of floor space. The bathroom had one sink in it, not two. The closet was large as well. I think how our room was laid out had to do with the large bathroom & closet. Each of the beds have the knitted blanket with he horse on it, a signature of the hotel. The elevator in the hotel is very old. I think that it might be from when the hotel opened. It's a little slow & rickety. We had a great time out, we got back to the hotel at 4:30am. The only room service available was a club sandwich or a chicken caesar salad. I got into the shower & found that the controls were a little confusing. I don't know if it was because I was a little intoxicated, but the gauge of the shower looked like from a 1955 Cadillac. I got into bed & I was surprised with how comfortable the bed was, it wasn't super soft, but it didn't feel like a stack of books either.We woke up in the morning & my boyfriend was feeling worse for wear, so we got packed up & left before we could try the "Hot Brown" sandwich, which is a nationally known sandwich that originated at the hotel. Our friends tried it & said it was amazing. Next time we are in we will have to stop by & try it.A lovely hotel filled with history. Friendly front staff.  Rooms were clean. Decor was appropriate, highlighting horses and racing.  Located very close to the medical center and within walking distance to many restaurants. Only took off one star because there were some shady people outside the hotel on 4th street asking for money which made me uncomfortable as I was walking around alone.My fiance and I were here for a little weekend getaway - from check in to check out, the hotel was a fantastic experience.The location was perfect - far enough away from the madness of Fourth Street and the bars on Main/Market, but close enough to walk there (or take a $5 Uber). The hotel offers free shuttle service to and from the airport, which is fantastic! It was maybe a 10-12 minute ride there.The rooms were spacious and clean. The bathroom was bit and well lit. my only small complaint was that we had one shampoo and two lotions (no conditioner) - I dont know if thats normal or if ours was just a mistake - but I accidentally lotioned my hair the first night (that'll teach me to only read two of the three bottles)We also had a small bite in the cafe downstairs - we split a hot brown and some fries... while tasty, it was extremely pricey ($18 for one piece of bread, a few slices of turkey, two slices of bacon, and cheese sauce?!?). When we split it, it was the perfect amount of food for us to hold us over for dinner a few hours later.Overall - the staff were friendly, the food was tasty, and the rooms were comfy... a great stay!The lobby bar is a nice place to visit--it's absolutely gorgeous and feels like visiting history--but is it worth the money? . . . that is the question. We tried the Hot Brown, minus the bacon, the unfortunately named signature dish of the Hotel (turkey and a rich sauce over bread and finished with slices of bacon), and the open-faced steak sandwich. They brought the Hot Brown out with bacon, and when we said we'd ordered it without bacon, they brought out a new one suspiciously quickly. The first few bites were very tasty, but the richness of it made me feel a little ill after a few minutes. As for the steak sandwich, it was really, really good. It was served with a sunny-side up egg (which I liked because it reminded me of brunch, which was what we were hoping to get at their downstairs restaurant but we arrived too late, quarter to 2:00 when they close at two, hrmph). I also very much enjoyed the chimichurri sauce served with the steak. When I think "Kentucky," I don't think "chimichurri" --and that's okay; it was a delightful surprise. The food arrived before the coffee we'd ordered as soon as we got our server's attention (he was slammed), so they did not charge us for it, which was nice. Overall, it's a lovely space, but I'm not convinced I would return.We spent a wonderful Derby Day at the Brown Hotel. We didn't have tickets to the Derby so wanted to find a fab place to watch it on the TV. The Brown delivered. The food & wine was excellent, the staff were so friendly and helpful and the venue is stunning. We could not have done better! If you are looking for a beautiful place to relax, eat and feel very welcome, the Brown Hotel is the place for you.We were in town for a family wedding and truly enjoyed joining our son and DIL for breakfast at The Brown Hotel Cafe. When you walk into The Brown it's easy to see why this historic hotel is a Louisville landmark. The ornate hand-painted plaster relief ceilings are beautiful!! The marble floors and mahogany furnishings give the lobby a warm welcome feel and truly does make a statement. The combination of old and new will make you fall in love with this hotel!  The Brioche French Toast was so delicious ~ thick brioche bread perfectly fried and served with fresh berries and warm maple syrup ~ YUM!At the end of the day we enjoyed relaxing at The Brown Hotel Lobby Bar for dessert and coffee. The cappuccino was a little strong, but the Chocolate Striptease dessert (milk chocolate mousse, espresso steam cake and salted caramel) was incredible! At the same time we ordered the Derby Pie ~ similar to pecan pie ~ with fresh berries. The berries were so good that we ordered an additional two bowls! The guys ordered, and split, The Hot Brown (roasted turkey breast and toast points covered with mornay sauce, pecorino romano cheese, baked golden brown and finished with bacon and tomatoes). The Hot Brown is a pretty good size dish so can easily be split. It's been a Louisville tradition since 1926 and definitely a dish worth trying! Our son and DIL stayed at The Brown and invited us up to their room. The rooms are spacious and beautiful ~ the bathroom alone was huge! The beds were covered with a soft Egyptian cotton linen with an Egyptian white down comforter and screamed "come lay on me and snuggle!"The Brown has free valet parking for patrons enjoying dinner at this beautiful hotel. From the valet guys to the wait staff, everyone was friendly and helpful. Although the rooms are very pricey, the restaurant prices are moderate.Overall: 5 stars.  The hotel did a great job in embracing it's history from the 1920's.  They had up-to-date touches but didn't lose the historic charm.  The service was top notch.  The room was a little cramped, but it was acceptable.Lobby & Lounge Area: 5 stars.  The hotel is from the 1920's, but was still up-to-date.  The decor and ceiling in the lobby were magnificent.  The main floor lounge bar was very nice and they had a great selection of local bourbons.  The elevator was a bit slow, but it's understandable with the age.The Room: The room was relatively small, but they fit in a desk, queen size bed and side table.  All the usual furnishings were there, but just not much open space.  The bed itself was very comfortable.  The real wood furniture and paintings were a nice touch over the typical fake stuff in mid-range hotels.Service: 5 stars.  Everyone was eager to help.Price: 4 stars.  The wedding block rate was $139 plus taxes and $20/night for self park.  This is higher than another wedding at the Hyatt ($110).  Free Wi-Fi was great.  Wedding: 5 stars.  We attended a wedding in the Crystal Ballroom.  It was beautiful and I liked how they had lounging areas with couches off from the main ballroom.Totally lived up to the billing. Took a cab right from the airport to the Brown (even though I'm staying there) to get me a Kentucky bourbon and hot brown. Sarah the bartender took great care of me. This is a must eat in downtown!We had a nice stay here over Labor Day weekend.  We'd originally wanted to stay at the 21c, but I balked at their high prices.  My husband said he once stayed at the Brown in the early days of Priceline for $25.  We definitely paid more than that this time, but we got a good deal on their website, especially considering it was a holiday weekend.  Our room was very nice, and it had no strange smells.  (I have a lot of allergies, so I hate rooms that smell moldy or musty, and I also hate rooms that smell like perfumes or cleaning products.  This room passed my test on both fronts!)  On the 12th floor, we had a great view of downtown Louisville, and the huge windows let in a lot of natural light.The package I booked online included a $20 meal credit, so we ate brunch in J. Graham's Cafe on the 2nd floor on Sunday morning.  The buffet is $26 per person, and we'd been considering splurging for it, but neither of us were that hungry, so we ordered off the menu instead.  Most items are in the $10 to $15 range, so you can save a lot of money that way.  It ended up costing the two of us $14 out-of-pocket after the meal credit and including tip.I'm not sure if I misunderstood or if something changed, but I'm pretty sure the package I signed up for also said it included free valet parking.  When we got there and had already given our car to the valet, the desk clerk said we were actually getting $4 off of valet parking, making it $20 instead of $24.  That's a pretty big difference, but since they already had our car and I couldn't find anything in writing about what our package included, we went with it.  The valets actually were wonderful during our stay.  When we realized we'd forgotten something in our car, they sent someone to get it for us, and they also got our car for us quickly and cheerfully every time we needed it during the weekend.  We never would have splurged for this service if we hadn't believed it to be free, but it was really, really nice, and it probably was worth $20.
review_content_20: My wife and I visited for a night to celebrate our 5 year anniversary. Let me split the review into two parts: the hotel and the room. The hotel atmosphere was incredible. You may recognize parts of the interior from the movie Elizabethtown, and it was chosen for the movie because it's stunning. My wife kept mentioning how the decor, music, and overall ambiance really helped to create an incredible experience with an old time feel. The bar had a long list of bourbons and offer various hotel packages that take advantage of their wide assortment of Kentucky themed cocktails. Both the English Grill and J. Grahams cafe were, overall, very pleasant.We stayed in a luxury king and the room was very spacious. Besides the space, the room was very average. There weren't any special amenities that made the space pop or the experience stand out. Overall, it was clean and slightly above average.I'd definitely recommend the hotel anyone looking for a special nights away in downtown Louisville.An old historic building with expansive public areas.The elevators can be painfully slow so be prepared to be patient.The bar service across from reception was exceptional. Both the bartender and staff were very attentive. Repeatedly refilling the bar snacks during my visit. Rooms are fairly large and comfortable. Somewhat dated, but still nice. Valet parking attendants were also very attentive and social. Overall the service is really what won me over about this hotel. Definitely will look to stay here again next time I'm in Louisville.LOVED our stay here. Wonderful service from everyone. Our room was beautiful, clean, and the bed was very comfortable. Yes, the hotel is old and it is an historic landmark. So everything isn't absolutely perfectly, but it has been well-cared-for and looks beautiful. We had "second dinner" late one evening at their lobby bar. We split their Hot Brown and I immediately regretted offering to split this with my husband. It was amazing - so good that we went back the next evening to order it again before we went out to dinner! Oh my - just delicious!!! If you are in Louisville, even if you don't stay here, you NEED to come here to order this dish!Valets were very friendly and helpful suggesting places we should see around town. In fact, service anywhere in this hotel was fantastic. They have complimentary beverages in the lobby at least in the afternoon and evening. However, when we checked out in the morning, there was nothing there. We had been hoping for coffee and went down to their cafe where a very nice server prepared coffee in to-go cups for us. This was a great experience - we would love to stay here again!First they pick you up for free from the airport. They have a phenomenal restaurant with great deserts. The J Graham's breakfast simply cannot be beat. The rooms are well appointed.  Rates are excellent. This is a great place to stay. Closets are huge. Fourth street is fun. Lots of restaurants.We reserved  the "Four Diamond" package for my 40th birthday. While not cheap at $375, it included a large king room on a club floor, access to the club lounge (free wine/beer/apps in the evening and continental breakfast in the a.m.), valet parking ($24 value) and a $100 dining credit in the English Grill. Oh, and a nice assortment of various Kentucky-related goodies, like some bbq sauces, shot glasses, a mug, a bedazzled horseshow, bourbon balls, and several other things. See, honey, it was a great value! Service was impeccable, starting at the front desk. (I had shamelessly mentioned it was my birthday. I'm no fool.) Even when we checked out the next day, I was wished a happy birthday. The hotel itself is gorgeous and seemed to attract and older crowd (most of the people on the club lounge seemed to be at least in their 60s). But, when we went to dinner, the lobby bar had a very mixed crowd, including many people in very casual dress, eating dinner. If you're looking for someplace hip, the Brown isn't for you. If you're looking for a place that has curtains that reminds you (and I'm showing my age here) the Carol Burnett "Gone with the Wind" sketch, make your reservation now!Had an outstanding experience staying here.- Complimentary shuttle service to/from the airport and nearby businesses.- Outstanding staff. Everyone was incredibly hospitable, warm, and welcoming. Eric H. in particular was outstanding.- Enjoyed wonderful food and drinks in the lobby bar.- Complimentary upgrade to the club level.- Very spacious and well-appointed rooms.- Convenient location- Beautiful, historic propertyWill definitely be staying here again should I find myself in Louisville.Staff from the Valet who greets you, to reception, to room service, to housekeeping were exceptional. The building is charming with the exact blend of modern updates (wifi, flat screen) and historic preservation. The room was well kept and quiet. The bed and linens were clean and comfortable after my long drive. Towel and toiletry supply was generous. But, the hot brown - that is the memory which will stay with me forever - quite simply the very best dish I've ever eaten. I'd got back to Kentucky just for the Hot Brown at The Brown. Special thanks to Angie T and Simone for all your help during my stay and seminar.We came here for a Valentine's Day weekend retreat. Honestly, we had hoped for better. We received terrible service everywhere we went. Our keys wouldn't open our door, so we were constantly going to and from the front desk. When we tried to have dinner and drinks at the bar downstairs, there were no waitresses. We sat at a table for 50 minutes before we decided to go up to the bar ourselves. Even then we had problems. There was a very loud group of men SHOUTING, I mean literally SCREAMING at the bar. They were so drunk, and no one even attempted to quiet them. Later in the night, one of the people from that disruptive group harassed me. There we were sitting in a fancy hotel, and it felt like we were at a trashy sports bar. Luckily we are pretty easy going, otherwise these things would have completely ruined our evening. Regardless, we will never stay here again and would caution others against doing so.when you've been at luxury hotel's in Vegas... its kinda spoils you.....But I am a fan of THE brown Hotel... rooms are some what simple.. but ... the luxury part of this hotel is the hotel itself the fact that its been here since the 1920's...the gorgeous ornate ceilings and marble floors are lovely... you do feel like ur in a 19 century movie... there has been a handful of movies filmed here ...  the structure is beautiful... your room its self is ok.... we were in the club deluxe king...unless of course you get into the suites.... I love the uber soft egyptian cotton sheets and down comforter... it was so nice to melt into.... the robes are ok they aren't as soft and comfy and certainly not worth $75. The beds are comfy and good quality... Finally a hotel where we can sleep and not complain about crappy beds...The service is good hereHouse keeping does a thorough job of cleaning your room,  i was in a hurry one morning and had all my makeup, hair products just everywhere in the bathroom and they neatly placed by things on a towel so they can still clean the vanity... love it... it was a relief coming back to our room so tidy..... also parking here is $20 a day for guest.. but ur in the perfect location here and they have a 24hr shuttle to and from the airport so u hardly need a car... They do have free valet for guest that are visiting the cafe, lobby bar, or their restaurant. WE love love the hotel lobby bar.... desserts are great... my motherinlaw had the striptease dessert, its one of those fire show desserts, its worth trying.We had the derby pie, if you like pecan pies you'll love the derby pie.  both desserts were served with berries, goods berries, raspberries, blackberries, and strawberries.. we love it so much we had to order two more bowls of just the berries.One night i had the mint julep mixed drink, its delicious... with a couple wedges of lemon, i like my drinks less sweet, so the lemon was perfect...That conditioner...oh, that complimentary, abnormally good conditioner. If your mane is part lion like my own, you probably understand that hotel conditioners (most often "conditioning shampoo") are weak to put it gently. So, first off, I want to applaud the Brown Hotel for sporting some killer conditioner yo! (Snaps, smiles, high fives all around)Other reasons I fancied my experience:-friendly and helpful staff-spacious rooms that make me think "Kentucky" and "old money" all rolled into one-historical charm that oozes throughout the architecture and interior design of the building-fantastic walkability- my morning walk led me to fourth street in around ten minutes-lastly, the fact that this is the original source of Kentucky's famous hot brown sandwich- how great is that, right?-I'm holding the fifth star (mainly half a star) because they could really use a vent in the bathrooms (steamy!) and the gal working the gift shop was less than friendly on the friendly spectrumHot Brown!  The only reason I went was to check it out.  Saw it a bunch of times on tv so I had to check it out.  People, this dish lives up to the hype. Out here on business and this was a destination spot before I headed south for work.  It's a big dish so you might to split it with your date but it wasn't a challenge for me since I had been flying all day.  Turkey is brined in house, cooked off and added to the Mornay sauce, Texas toast, and house cured bacon.  There was a group of about 8 people and every single one of them ordered the Hot Brown.  Good choice!  And too bad I had a long drive because the bar has about 50 bottles of the local Kentucky liquid gold.  It's a old hotel (built in 1920s - thanks for the history Greg(?)).  Anyway, you'll have  stop in and have one.  You won't be pegged a tourist if you order one.This hotel is seriously beautiful and a really great experience.  They have preserved the 1920's feel of the hotel in a great way.  The rooms are definitely more traditionally decorated and the bathrooms are on the small side, but it wasn't an issue for us.  We upgraded to the deluxe room so we had a nice large sitting area and walk in closet as well which was nice. The staff were great and super accommodating.  We had just gotten a new car, and asked the valet to try to park it away from other cars if he could- and he actually put cones around our car for us!  It's within walking distance of some great restaurants and conveniently located in general.  Will definitely be adding this to the top of the list of places to stay in Louisville!An art nouveau treasure.  If you enjoy beautiful spaces, you would enjoy eating here.  I haven't stayed at the hotel overnight, but I have eaten at the bar several times.  Sure, you're going to be sitting with a lot of middle aged dudes in polo shirts and golf hats, but you can imagine that once upon a time there were young hipsters wearing white pants and navy blazers dancing the night away.   When those guys (and their flapper gals) got tired, they needed a late-night snack.  And what the Brown Hotel came up with for them was the hot brown sandwich.   A calorie bomb consisting for two slices of bread, turkey, bechamel sauce, parmesan cheese, and topped with two strips of bacon since before bacon was cool, the hot brown will really hit the spot.  Basically if you come to Louisville and haven't had a hot brown, you've wasted your trip!   The drinks are way expensive, but you may as well get something with bourbon since you're in Kentucky.   Oh, and since the hot brown isn't sufficiently calorie-rich, you'd better finish with a slice of derby pie....mmmm.....   Last tip, for some reason, the hot brown is a few bucks cheaper if you get it in the bar as opposed to in the restaurant.I had seen the Brown on TV and since I was in Louisville I decided to drop by and try the famous "Hot Brown" sandwich. It did not disappoint!  This sandwich is probably one of the top 10-20 things I have ever eaten in my life and that's no exaggeration. Eating in the lobby bar at The Brown made it even better. What an amazing place!  The decor is immaculately preserved right out of the 1920s and the hotel is stunningly beautiful. The waitress was a lot of fun, the staff was extremely friendly, and having a whiskey list with 50+ choices really sets this place apart. Free valet parking for diners helps too!Old style hotel. Maybe, doesn't have all the features the new build have,  but what's matter have, people who care. Excellent customer care. One small gesture, I was reading in the lobby when employee approached me and asked: "Would you like a glass of water". That doesn't happen often.What a wonderful getaway! The food was amazing and the room was incredible. The staff was very responsive and every request was done quickly with a smile.Beautifully restored hotel! My date wanted to try the original Kentucky Hot Brown and Kentucky Derby Pie. Since we shared, they split our plate without prompting; always a nice thing! Both items were delicious, but my favorite was the pie.With the caveat that I did not stay here, I did spend a bunch of time here for a conference.This is a nice historic hotel and the staff are very friendly.  The venue was very good for a conference.  I would have stayed here, but the rooms were full when I booked.Definitely and interesting place.This is an update to a previous review...spent several nights at the Brown in December and have to say the service staff was outstanding and my room(s) were extremely comfortable and of course the food, whether at the bar or room service was just excellent.  If you've got to be stuck somewhere over Christmas...the Browns not a bad place to be.Drove down to try the Hot BrownFor Valentines Day with my sweetie. He made reservations for our special occasion. We decided to split a hot brown and their special of the day which was supposed to be a pulled pork sandwich with Cajun onion rings.The hot brown was so delicious, smooth and creamy sauce that smothered the crustless lightly toasted bread with a generous cut of tender juicy turkey. We wished we didn't have to share the portion. It was perfect.
review_content_40: The most important aspects of a stay at any hotel is bed comfort, cleanliness, quiet.The beds are made with a flat sheet on the bottom, so before you even get in bed, turning down the top un-makes the bed. Sleep in it for an hour and it looks someone dumped a pile of laundry on a mattress. The bedding is of low quality, polyester feel. The room is clean, 550$ gets you that. The lobby and street level area ( lobby is on the second floor) not so clean. Classic, beautiful public areas, but dirty carpet, worn furniture, big messes of wires very visible. Full trash cans downstairs, loose handles on main entry doors.Staff is noisy in the halls. Engineering can be heard doing maintenance. Doors are allowed to slam shut by housekeeping (a supervisor with a clipboard)Service was great. Plumbing is definitely OLD.  Shower was a bit dark because of the shower curtain, but none of these factors would deter us from returning. I only mention this for the more discerning customers.The room was gigantic with a couch. We went with  2 other couples, and the large room size lended itself to socialization with our other friends.  The gift shop in the basement is nice and includes a large selection of Bourbon Barrell Foods, and other large-brand bourbon products (candy, sauces, etc).  We ate at the more expensive restaurant in the hotel and it was excellent.  I got the Hot Brown, because it's legendary.  It was good, but I recommend getting a salad and sharing the Hot Brown with someone else.  It was heavy and high in fat, and you really can't eat all of it.   Our friends got a Hot Brown at other restaurants in town, and it did not compare to the one at The Brown Hotel.  This is definitely the best looking/tasting one we saw and found. :)Great place! Love everything about this hotel it's such a charmer! I've stayed here 3 times and every time was spectacular! Can't wait to go back!We absolutely loved this hotel. Great old world charm, loved the bar in the hotel lobby for an old fashion or manhattan and truffle fries. It was as good as it gets. Then we walked everywhere else to do our bourbon tasting. Great location to restaurants and bars in downtown.Okay so I just returned from Louisville and while I was there the wife and I tried the famous Hot Brown sandwich. I may have given a 4th star under different circumstances. Well I must say the flavor profile was delicious as you can imagine. The only problem I had was the excessive and I mean excessive amount of pure oil in the dish. This oil is a by product of bacon, cheese and over buttered toast points. Way to much residual oil on the plate. I actually watched another patron ask for paper napkins to dab off the collection of grease on her plate. I wish I would have had the courage to ask for paper napkins in a linen napkin type lobby bar. There is little texture profile in this dish, I expected a crunch of the toast points but was met with soggy over buttered crouton like toast.  I was disappointed by the service, it was lacking indeed. We arrived at the lobby literally 3 minutes before opening and were told they were opening shortly. well after it turned 3 o'clock I again asked if they were open, I was given a slightly snarky answer and proceeded to sit with my wife. It was quite awhile before the single bartender (Forest) took our order, The place was filling up fast and no help was given to Forest, the only guy making drinks, taking food orders, delivering food, filling water glasses basically doing the work of 3 to 4 staff members by himself. All the while a well dressed young manager type walked around asking how we were doing. Ultimately this fella  needed to help Forest with the grunt work and  after A while he finally had no choice but to do work. I understand southern charm and a slow relaxed approach to a meal but this was excessive. I am very happy I had the experience of the famous Brown Hotel and its classic dish but if this were any other place I may not have been so kind with my review. You cant rest on tradition and reputation alone you must always remember the customer experience is number one!I have to include this bit of information to my review. My wife and I went to J. Graham's Cafe earlier in the day around 9 or 10 am in search of a  bloody Mary. I must say this experience was absolutely FANTASTIC. The bartender, manager and other staff members were GREAT! The Friday morning (4-24-2015) manager and his staff should teach the others a lesson in hospitality, thank you guys! I returned later in the day with the expectation of the same treatment, this didn't work out so good. All in all it was a really fun time experiencing a piece of Kentucky history in a fabulous city.Beautiful room! We would stay here again if we and the chance. Check in was a little hectic, valet guys were friendly nice guys and you gotta grab that hot brown!Stayed here this past weekend for 2 nights. Lovely hotel, nicely decorated and very clean. Unfortunately, our room was right by the elevator (1025) and it was so loud with people waiting for the elevator that I barely slept either night. I should have requested another room, but didn't. This room is also directly above the valet stand, which can get loud. Request a room not by the elevator and you should have a better experience! If we were in town again, we would definitely consider this hotel.I heard about this place when I was googling about Louisville. I heard about how beautiful the inside was with all of its history. Those reviews were all right. This place is amazing inside, the attention to detail, the ceilings, the wood carving, the history, it was all so beautiful. We didn't stay here, but it was definitely worth walking to and checking out the inside.My boyfriend and I sat down at the Lobby bar and had a few Bourbon drinks and the bartender Forrest was so nice and extremely informative. He helped us plan what Bourbon Distilleries we were going to go to the next day. He also gave us some good insights on things we have to do while in town.This is my favorite place to stay downtown. It's like taking a step back in preserved time. The staff was incredible and the place is always immaculate.First time ever being here.  Service was a bit slow and more than just in the nice place slow meal kind of way.  Probably backed up a bit because they had only one bartender.  I of course got the Hot Brown.  It was very good, but I've had one or two others that I prefer a bit more.  Mostly the sauce was a bit lacking in flavour.  The bacon and turkey were both higher quality than most places, however.A very nice place to visit because of the history and the great food. I would definitely go back. The Ali Smash is a great drink & I really enjoyed the truffle fries. We ate in the lobby bar and that was great to people watch and have a casual lunch. The Hot Brown is incredible and not overly heavy with the sauce which I thought it would be.I love historic hotels -- especially those with southern charm, and this definitely fit the bill.  Stayed here on government rate, and at check-in, they asked to see my government ID.  Local government IDs accepted -- just an FYI.  If you plan to stay here on government rate, you will have to call or email regarding the rate.Parking here is kind of pricey - it's either $16 or $20, depending on if you want in & out privileges.  For me, I was only going to stay in Louisville overnight with no ins and outs, so I paid $16 for overnight parking versus $20 (in and out privileges).  The hotel is conveniently located in downtown Louisville with lots of restaurants and night life in the nearby vicinity.  Because the hotel is located in a downtown area, a late night walk can feel a bit sketch.  However, nothing happened during my walk around downtown -- even at 10-11pm.My room was quite roomy, well appointed, and historic feeling -- just the way I liked it.  The only issue I had was that the window in my room was slightly ajar and I couldn't close it.  It was kind of late by the time I figured out why there was a draft in my room, so I didn't bother calling maintenance to fixing the issue.  So as a recommendation to anyone coming to stay here, check your window and make sure it's closed (or you can close it!).Other great perks about this place is free internet and very friendly staff.   Oh... I also really love the architecture of the hotel lobby.  When you step inside, you feel like you've stepped back in time -- back to the early 1900's -- a feeling that you don't get with many modern hotels these days.  Just hanging out in the lobby really makes you appreciate the beauty of the art & architecture from yesteryear.Hands down it's THE HOT BROWN! Add in a Woodford Reserve bourbon and now you are living babycakes ! Add to that the 90 year old surroundings and a polite polished staff and you've got something you can ONLY do in Louisville Kentucky in this one sweet spot. A city to behold beauties too! What's in the water because ... WOW!we had a fair experience here.-1 for starters, their website never sent a confirmation email after having made the reservation+1 for professional, courteous, and on-the-ball staff.  the level of service we received throughout our stay was far above average.  not just front desk, but also valet staff, cleaning crew, etc.+1 for a beautiful lobby.  clearly, the hotel is using the lobby as its focal point.-1 for dated decor, even in the lobby.  the furniture could use some steam-cleaning.  various improvements could be made that would make a big difference.-1 for a smaller-than-expected king room.+1 for a larger-than-expected bathroom, by area.  however, the space wasn't all usable.-1 for a TV remote that didn't work.+1 for drapes that actually keep the room dark.+0 for average quality linens.  not what we were expecting from a hotel like this.-1 for being stingy with towels.  2 sets of towels, with no extras whatsoever.-1 for no refrigerator in the room.-1 for completely average workout room.  a couple treadmills, a couple ellipticals, and one stationary machine.  pretty small.+1 for great drinks at the lobby bar.  specifically, my wife loved the mint julep.  my bourbon flight was pretty good.-1 for not a great part of town.tip:  avoid parking in the hotel garage.  there is a $3/day lot caddy-corner from the brown, and a $2/day lot southwest of the hotel off of 5th street.for what we paid, i had higher expectations.  recommended for the historical experience, but other than that, you can find better elsewhere.The lobby is awe-inspiring. I think I'll need a neck massage due to my perpetual staring at the ceiling. Truly, this hotel is beautiful. I only stayed one night, but The Brown earned high marks from me. The rooms themselves aren't too much to write home about. Yes, the beds are comfortable. You'll find the typical amenities like a flat screen TV, desk, free WiFi (not the most consistent signal) and decent sized bathroom. Frankly, if it were just based on the room, I'd dole out just three stars. But there's more...The staff at this hotel are nothing short of fantastic. They are friendly and helpful without being intrusive. They remember your name even if you've only been there a few hours. That, my friends, is impressive. Special high five to the bellmen and Nicole in the lobby bar. The neighborhood is pretty cool and many of the surrounding areas are being rehabbed and developed. I'd stay at The Brown again and certainly make my way back to the lobby bar for another cocktail.Be sure to stop in at the Brown Hotel, second floor lobby bar when you're in Louisville. Try an Old Fashioned and the crispy pork belly sliders. Let the knowledgeable bar tender select the bourbon for the drink but "slap the hands" of anyone who tries to sample your sliders... the jam served on the side is outstanding! Just an enjoyable time.Can't get enough of those Hot Browns!  Very flavorful and rich, but not overly-filling in the way that makes you feel regret after eating.I had a couple Hot Browns from the lobby bar while I was staying at the Brown Hotel for the weekend.  I'll really miss them as they don't serve them in my part of the country.The only thing that could improve is the cocktails (mine was so sweet it was almost undrinkable) and the service was a bit slow for how few people were there.Came for the hot brown, got maimed by the womens bathroom toilet paper holder!This 'sandwich" is really a hot bubbly yum fest. Watch out, you will tip the scales afterwards.  Its heavy cream, butter and flour which tastes divine.  Then, some yummie texas toast and real turkey breast topped with bacon.  We ordered one and they split it for us, how nice!  We each had our our little griddle plate. Then I used the rest room and BAM!  Ouch! That toilet paper dispenser is a killer...seriously, thought my arm was broken, beware ladies!$16 for the sammie and not price tag high enough for the way my elbow spazes when the weather changes now....lolI stayed at The Brown Hotel on a recent work trip to Louisville. The historic hotel (built in the 1920's) is long on charm. The art deco  style has been well preserved throughout the hotel and 1920's jazz is played softly in the hotel lobby. The staff were extremely friendly. My room was very spacious and very nicely appointed with portraits of horses and equestrians (the hotel is located near the Kentucky Derby afterall). The only thing I wasn't completely enamored with was the bathroom, the shower drain was clogged and the water pressure was very low. But kudos for the free WiFi throughout the entire hotel! The location was also good, only 3 blocks from the downtown Louisville nightlife. Overall, The Brown is a fabulous historic hotel in a great location for exploring Louisville.I may have developed a delicate drawl, just by staying here for one night. Amazing!It's hard not to feel transformed for a moment while surrounded by the historic, elegant and grand decor. And even though "Southern Belle" in me really didn't appear, as I sat in the regal lobby full of antique furniture and leather sofas, I kind of felt like I should have a Mint Julep in my hand. The rooms were nice, albeit a little old-fashioned and it kind of annoyed me that the TV has to be awkwardly pulled out and angled towards the bed. The bathroom is simple and the closet space is huge (although not sure who would need that much space unless they planned an extended visit.)I even had a chance to visit the restaurant and try the infamous, Hot Brown sandwich!Overall, I had a pretty good experience here although I'm not sure that I would recommend it for anyone looking for a hip, fun place to stay. However, for the historic value alone I think it's worth the stay!
review_content_60: I frequently stay at The Brown for work. I have a few things I genuinely like and others I don't particularly care for.Positives:When you first walk you're greeted by a very polite staff and walk above to one of the nicest lobbies I have stood in. The honeycomb-style ceiling is the main feature because it is so detailed and in pristine condition. The same can be said for the old timey decor and registration desk. It's a beautiful place to get married.The food and drinks are excellent. The birthplace of the Hot Brown. Can't go wrong.It's a great location. Blocks away from Fourth Street Live.Negatives:Not the most ideal for extended stays unless you're a ghost. There are rumors of unexplained happenings in the hotel. Adds to the hotels fun and intrigue for some.The old timey feel follows you throughout the hotel. The halls are creepily decorated with side tables stacked with books and one chair. Retro restraint would be greatly appreciated in the common areas.The same can be said for the rooms. It a crap shoot if you'll have a great room or a eerie room. My last room was very nice. All the bathrooms are nicely updated. However, the rooms haven't been as nice due to the layout and decor. I think I'm more accustomed to a more modern ambiance.Overall:I like the hotel. Incredible for a boutique stay or big wedding. The food is excellent. I would like to feel more comfortable in my rented room. I would walk from another hotel to enjoy their bar and restaurant.Not bad at all. Good location. Great decor. Room was spacious and very clean. Could use some modernization like more updated gym equipment, better plumbing and tv. The best part of my stay was the housekeeping...they get 5 out of 5 for me but overall the hotel is 4 stars. I'd definitely come back.How can you come to Louisville and not get a Hot Brown from the Brown Hotel?! You may want to skip a meal or 3 before ordering this mass of deliciousness as it contains your daily suggested calories in a single meal. Don't believe me? Google it. I won't list the entire list of ingredients but let's just say that 14 oz of turkey, 2 oz of whole butter and 16oz of heavy cream are just the beginning!Looking back at the list of ingredients, I think it contains more than a day's worth of calories. And since we were on a fat kid binge, why not top off such a great meal with a slice of derby pie?! This place is not to be missed and whatever you order, make sure to get at least one hot brown to share at your table. It is a Louisville icon and worth every once of heavy cream it contains! My mouth waters just thinking about it.Hotel may be okay, but their people are unaccountable for their actions ( like not leaving enough light in a very dark hallway leading to the bathrooms.  My elderly father didn't see 4 or 5 steps that lead down to the bathrooms and fell, landed on his head.  He had to be rushed to the hospital and when we asked The Brown Hotel what they were going to do about this, we were told that my father should have been more careful - although they admitted it was "a little hard to see." ... They don't accept responsibility and I have nothing good to say about the arrogant people who work there.I stayed here for Kentucky Derby 2014. The Brown Hotel is beautifully preserved, with attractive historical decor and architecture, modern bathrooms, perfectly comfy beds and linens, and wonderfully professional and friendly service.I'm usually cautious of old hotels because sometimes they rest on their laurels and end up being creepy, creaky and spooky. This is NOT the case of The Brown Hotel. It is the best combination of modern and traditional.My Mother learned to make Hot Browns back in the early 30's and the recipe was passed on to me and I have been making them the same way for 50 years. What you get at the Brown Hotel bears little resemblance to the original. They seem to be using 3/4" thick breast slices off of some type of turkey roll that they no doubt purchase from a food vendor such as Sysco.  I suppose it is not unenjoyable for the novice and the Mornay sauce is passable but the whole thing is only about 20% as good as what it could and should be.What can i say about the "hot brown". Sounds kinda awkward, but its actually an open faced turkey sandwich with a mornay cheese sauce, roasted tomato, and bacon. I think a part of me died when i took my first bite, because i swear i saw heaven. Food was really delicious and the service was quick and polite. Definitely would go back to kentucky to eat here againStaying at this hotel was a wonderful experience.  I stayed for two nights as part of a wedding party.  The decor in this place is awesome.  I was expecting it to be tacky and weird, but it looks amazing.  It is certainly over the top but it definitely works!  It is expensive considering it's in downtown Louisville but I was able to book at a lower rate due to being military ($107/night).  My room was awesome.  The best part was the view.  I was on the 8th floor and my bathroom had an entire wall that was just windows.  I could see downtown Louisville while taking a pee!  Amazing.  The bed was very comfortable and the room was immaculate.  The one thing that kinda but a damper on the charm was the ugly tub.  It was your average tub you can find at a cheap motel, but whatever.
